text: 'Paying for Trash Some places want families to pay for each bag of trash they make. This sounds good for the environment and money, but it might not work well. In many countries, trash is picked up for free. Families pay for this with local taxes. A family with a lot of trash pays the same as a family with little trash. But more trash means more trucks and workers are needed, which costs more money. If trash pickup is free, people might make too much trash. One idea is to make families pay for each bag of trash. This might make them throw away less and recycle more. But two American economists, Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman, found that this idea can have problems. They looked at some American towns that started charging for trash. People had to buy stickers for their trash bags. Only bags with stickers were picked up. In Charlottesville, Virginia, people paid 80 cents for each bag. The number of bags went down by 37%, but people just put more trash in each bag. The weight of trash went down by only 14%. In other towns without this system, trash went down by 3.5% anyway. Some people also dumped trash illegally to avoid paying. Recycling went up by 15%, but many people were already recycling. Fullerton and Kinnaman found that charging for trash does not reduce it by much. A 10% increase in sticker price only cuts trash by 0.3%. People would need to buy less of everything to make a big change. Other things like income and education might also affect how much trash people make. Richer towns throw away more trash and have less time to recycle. Charging for trash is not a bad idea, but it is complicated. Simple ideas can have complex results.'

'Work Theodore Zeldin talks about how our jobs might change. Do people respect and appreciate you at work? Just having a good job is not enough anymore. Many people feel their jobs are not valued. Even famous people can feel unhappy. Before, loving your job was special. Now, you need to think about how your job affects you as a person. Does it make you happy? Does it help you grow? If your job makes you boring or too busy, no money or status can make you feel good. I want to find out how work can make people happy and help them grow. Work should not just be about making money. It should help us live better lives and meet new people. But this does not mean everyone will have a job. People want jobs that make them happy and are interesting. Work should be like art, with happy people at the center. Many jobs are not as good as they used to be. Doctors are stressed, accountants worry about their work, and architects cannot be creative. Managers are not happy with their jobs. Companies are getting smaller. New ideas like making decisions together and rewarding good work are not working well. In Britain, only 8% of workers feel their values match their company's values. I am looking at different jobs to see how they affect people. I study what people can do and how they can be brave. I look at happiness, love, friendship, and respect. Now, I am looking for better ways to work. Many experts help companies make more money, but we also need to think about what makes us happy. How many people feel alive at work? How many feel like they are stuck in their jobs? For example, hotel workers often have low pay and long hours. Hotels have not changed much since the past. They could be places where people from different countries meet and learn from each other. Hotel workers could do more than just simple tasks. If hotels cared about their workers' dreams, they could offer more services. But accountants say hotels should focus on making money. We need to think about work from a human side, not just a money side. Work is about relationships. People want to be independent and choose their jobs and coworkers. They need to talk to people from different jobs. Communication is important, but real conversation is more. It helps people understand each other and feel equal. Every good conversation can change the world a little bit.'

Broadcasting means sending out information to many people. A long time ago, broadcasting meant planting seeds by hand. Now, it means sending words and pictures to people, like on TV. 
TV started as a way to send information from one place to many homes. This was because of how society and business worked. People tried other ways, like two-way TV, but they did not last. In the 1930s, people watched TV in public places, not just at home. 
Big companies wanted to sell TVs for homes, so they made rules for TV equipment. As more people could buy TVs, watching at home became normal. This was part of modern life, where people moved around more and lived in smaller groups. 
Broadcasting helped governments share important news with everyone. It also helped people feel connected to their country. Broadcasting was important for democracy, letting people join in political and cultural life. 
Today, TV and broadcasting are changing. The way we use these technologies might be different in the future.

**Clutter**  
Sometimes, it feels like having many things does not make you feel safe. It is normal to want a home that is nice and meets your needs. But sometimes, wanting more things can become too much. Advertisements try to make us feel like we need more things. They say, "If you don't have this, you are not good enough." Next time you walk down the street, try not to look at any ads. Ads are everywhereâ€”on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, shirts, and the internet. They all tell us to buy more things.
**Caves**  
People all over the world study caves. They want to know where caves come from, how water moves in them, and what lives in them. Caves are interesting and make us curious. Many people study caves because they are a part of nature. Some people study caves for fun, and some do it for science. You need to be fit to visit many caves, so not just professors study them. Both professionals and people who love caves for fun learn about them.
**Weather Watch**  
A long time ago, people watched the weather with just their eyes. This helped start the study of weather, called meteorology. Today, we use satellites and computers to learn about the weather. Computers do math very fast to help us understand the weather. But human experience is still important. People can see things that computers cannot. This helps make better weather forecasts.

**Music and Theatre**
I used to think opera was mostly theatre. But now I know music is more important in opera. I come from theatre, where words and actors are very important. In theatre, the audience and actors usually speak the same language. 
In music, like in a concert or opera, many people do not know much about music. They might feel shy about this. But they admire the musicians' skills. Musicians work very hard for many years. Watching them is like watching athletes. We know they do something similar to us, but much better.
Theatre audiences have different expectations. They do not always understand how hard acting is. They are not always impressed by long speeches. But they often ask actors, "How do you remember all those lines?" 
Theatre and music audiences can be the same people. But in theatre, the audience and actors are more equal. Music can learn from theatre about this relationship. Music is full of feelings and can be like theatre. But music often feels formal, with dress codes and respect for conductors and soloists. 
Sometimes, music audiences clap at the wrong time. This can interrupt the performance. But many people are working to make music more welcoming. I remember a special event with music in a cathedral and town. It was amazing and changed many people's lives. 
I want music to take more risks, like theatre. Sometimes, using new places for music can surprise everyone. It might be uncomfortable, but it can be exciting. I love both theatre and music. I want more people to enjoy them like I do.

**Sand**  
I do not like sand very much. Sand can become glass and concrete, which is useful. But on the beach, sand is not nice. It gets in your face and in your food. It hides things like car keys and coins. When you are wet, sand sticks to you and is hard to remove. But when you step on a towel or get in a car, sand falls off. You find sand in your shoes and socks for days. Sand stays with you for a long time. I do not want sand.
**Lock and Key**  
People want their homes to be safe. Long ago, people used a beam to lock doors. Now, we use electronic locks with cards. But people like using a key. At work, electronic locks are okay. At home, people like to use a key. One company made a new lock with a key and electronic system.
**Modern Art**  
I was worried about going to the new Tate Modern gallery. I do not understand modern art. I like some art, like furry things and big photos. I do not know much about art. Art should talk to you, but it does not work for me. The new gallery helps people understand art. There are labels that explain the art. The labels help me understand the pictures.

**Making Movies from Books**
When we make a movie from a book, we often have to cut out parts. This can be hard for the writer, but it can also help us see what is important. When I worked on a movie script, I saw that I could remove some words and still tell the same story. This does not mean the book had too many words. Books and movies tell stories in different ways. In books, we often repeat things to help the reader understand. In movies, we show things with pictures.
**Watching Movies**
When we watch a movie, we feel like we are in a different world. We forget about real life for a while. But when the movie ends, we come back to the real world. Some people think movies are just for fun and not art. They like movies but do not think they are important.
**The Film Studios**
The Leiper Film Company studios had many different buildings. It was hard to find your way around. There were three main doors, but only one took you where you wanted to go. It was confusing for new people, but the workers knew their way. The workers made movies that people loved to watch.
**Making Movies**
Many people want to make movies. There are books and classes to help them learn. Some people make movies with little money, like Robert Rodriguez. He made a movie for $7,000 and became famous. In the past, people took a long time to learn how to make movies. They worked on small projects first. Now, people often start making movies on their own.

In those days, many houses were on the west side of the city. They were small and not very nice. In summer, a factory nearby made the air smell bad. In the morning, a paperboy would hold his nose because of the smell.
I don't remember much from when I was young. But I do remember sitting by a window and looking at the houses. I also remember my mother. She was small and often angry. I didn't know why she was angry, so I couldn't make her happy. She liked to be alone, even with many people around. She wanted everything to be very clean and proper. She told me to "behave proper," but I didn't understand what she meant.
My mother had some friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who liked the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who didn't talk much, and Mrs. Laband, who was more lively. They talked about things like the weather and their children. I felt like I was one of the children they talked about.
Growing up in West Earlham was the same for everyone. Before you were five, you stayed at home. I remember playing on a rug while my mother sat in a chair. After you turned five, you went to school. Some kids had a mother with a bike to take them. My mother let other kids take me to school.
I remember the summer holidays. Sometimes, I saw things outside West Earlham. There was an old man who told stories about the sea. Once, I went to a charity event where a nice woman gave lemonade. She wanted me to join a group, but my mother said no because she thought they just wanted money.
My mother didn't like politicians. She thought they took money from people. But she cared about my education. Sometimes, we went to the Norwich Castle Museum. We looked at paintings. My mother even made a joke once about a painting of a Roman soldier. She said, "I wouldn't like to meet him on a dark night!"

Philadelphia Avenue
I walked down Philadelphia Avenue. It was getting dark, and the air was wet. I knew this street well. My neighbors, the Matzes and the Pritchards, lived here. There was also Han Kieffer's grocery store. My friends lived in the houses on this street. When I was a child, I played here. The street goes downhill, and the houses change. Some houses became stores, and some stores became houses again.
Bachelor Fads
Rick Gilbert lives in a big, open apartment. It used to be a curtain warehouse. The apartment has big doors and brick walls. Rick did not want one big open space. He used a big plastic wall to make different rooms. The kitchen is in the middle. Rick likes to cook for friends and make coffee for work. He has modern chairs and old furniture from his parents.
Bruce Chatwin
Bruce Chatwin was a writer. He liked to travel and write about his trips. His first book, "In Patagonia," was very good. He mixed real stories with made-up ones. He wanted to show that travel can teach us about history and exciting stories.
Swimming
One summer, it rained a lot. I went swimming in the pool behind my house. The rain made bubbles in the water. I thought about swimming a long way across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain to the sea. Swimming is a way to see the world differently. It helps us find places that are still wild and mysterious.

'CRYING Charles Darwin thought that crying did not have a clear purpose. He was probably wrong. Scientists now say crying is important for social reasons. Psychiatrist John Bowlby said crying helps mothers and children bond. Many people think children cry because they feel helpless. But why do adults cry? It is not easy to explain. The sound of crying is less important than seeing someone cry. Crying might have helped early humans trust each other and feel connected. We can cry for other reasons too. We might cry when we feel sorry for someone. We might cry when we hear beautiful music or speeches. We might cry when watching a sad movie, especially with other people. Crying seems to have a social purpose, but scientists are still studying it.'

**The Heat is On**
Global warming means the Earth is getting warmer. We are not sure how much warmer it will get or how it will change our lives. A warmer Earth can change the weather everywhere. This can affect plants, animals, water, and soil. We use these things to grow food and build cities. Changes to these are important.
In the last 100 years, people have put more gases in the air. These gases make the Earth warmer. Scientists think this is because of pollution. They use computers to study the weather and make guesses about the future. These guesses are not perfect, but they help us understand what might happen.
By the year 2100, the Earth might be 1 to 3.5 degrees Celsius warmer. The sea level might rise by 15 to 95 cm. There might be more heatwaves, floods, and droughts. These changes can affect where plants and animals live and how we get food and water.
Some changes might be good. For example, in Australia, warmer weather has helped grow more wheat. But many changes might be bad. Less water might be available in dry places. Ice might melt, changing the land and sea. The Arctic ice might disappear, making it easier to travel by sea but also more dangerous.
The sea level rising is a big problem. Many people live near the coast. If the sea rises, places like London, New York, and Tokyo could have big problems. People might lose their homes and need to move. Small islands might disappear completely. This would be very hard for the people living there.

'Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged, married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars and back. Applicants must be strong and healthy. This is the plan of Dennis Tito, a rich man, to send a spaceship on 5 January 2018. The spaceship will go 160 km above Mars. It will use Mars' gravity to come back to Earth without using more fuel. This is important because the next chance to go to Mars is in 2031. New technology is needed for this trip. If everything is ready in time, the spaceship might go. Even if it does not go, the work will help future space trips.'

Title: Art and Everyday Life
Art is something we see in buildings, books, paintings, and statues. People often think art is just these objects. But art is more than that. It is about what these objects make us feel and think.
Sometimes, we forget this because some art is very famous and old. We admire it without thinking about why it was made or how it makes us feel today. This makes it hard to understand art.
Art should not be separate from our daily lives. It is like a mountain that is part of the earth. To understand art, we need to look at our everyday experiences. We should see art in things like movies, music, and comics. These are things people enjoy every day.
To understand art, we need to look at the simple things around us. We should enjoy the colors, sounds, and feelings they give us. Art is not just in museums. It is in our daily lives, in the things we see and hear every day.

**Observing Lions**
Lions are big cats. People think lions hunt together like a team. They hide and then catch their food. Lions live in groups. They work together to find food and take care of baby lions. But, sometimes, lions do not always work well together. We started watching lions in 1978. We wanted to know why they help each other. Lions can live for many years. We are still learning about them.
**Pop Music Review**
Bedrock is a music band. They made a new album called "New Life." This album changed rock music. The music is fun and has different sounds. The songs talk about life and feelings. The album has 16 songs, and all are very good.
**Extract from an Autobiography**
As a child, I liked stories about wise women called "The Sibyl." My mother told me a story about an old woman and a king. The woman had nine books. She sold three books to the king for a lot of money. I learned a lesson from this story. I was sometimes lonely. My mother said to do fun things so other kids would want to play with me. It worked. I like to write about places. I like to think about old things and history.
**What Becomes of Your Manuscript?**
When you write a book, you send it to a publisher. The book waits in a pile. A young person or an older person reads it first. If they like it, they show it to a boss. The boss decides if the book is good. They think about how many people will buy it. They also want to know if the writer can help sell the book. Sometimes, they meet the writer before saying yes.

**Advertising Challenges in the 1990s**
In the early 1990s, people working in advertising had a hard time. The economy was bad, and many people lost their jobs. In Britain, in 1991, the economy went down, interest rates were high, and people spent less money. Many homes were taken back by banks, and businesses like car and building companies lost a lot of money.
Advertising workers felt a lot of pressure. They had to do more work with less money. Companies wanted to make sure they sold things people wanted, not just what was easy to make. This made marketing more important, but also harder.
In the 1980s, advertising was very successful. But in the 1990s, it was difficult. Companies started to look closely at how much money they spent on advertising. They wanted to know if it was worth it. Many companies were not sure if advertising was helping them.
Companies wanted better advertising. They wanted good ideas and good places to show their ads. They wanted the best people to work hard for them. Advertising people had to find ways to do more with less money.
There were other problems too. The economy was bad, and there were new rules about advertising. People wanted different things, and companies had to think about advertising in other countries.
Advertising people had to make sure more of their ads worked well. But it was hard to find help or advice. Companies that did well kept their secrets. Books and talks about advertising did not always help.
In the end, advertising people had to work very hard to make good ads with less money.

**The Kitchen Dream**
When I was at university, I wanted to be a chef. This was not common. Most people did not want to cook. Being a chef is hard. The work is long and not paid well. But I still wanted to do it. I was not happy at university. The work was hard, and I did not like the social life. Cooking seemed better. It felt real and honest. I first wanted to cook after eating at a famous restaurant in London. The food was amazing. I wanted to know how to make food like that. I started reading cookbooks and cooking a lot. My history degree was not important to me anymore.
**Learning to Dive**
The swimming teacher was a small, strong man with tattoos. I asked him to teach me to dive. He told me to sit at the pool's edge, put my hands up, and roll forward. I practiced this a lot. Next time, I stood up and dived from the edge. The teacher was strict. He said, "Don't look down, look up!" and "Keep your legs straight." The next week, I went to the high board. It was very high. I was scared but jumped. For a moment, I felt like I was flying. I did not dive well, but I was happy. I felt free like a bird.
**The Traveller**
Some people like a comfortable bed and running water. But some people like adventure. They climb high mountains and sail alone in the sea. They eat strange food if they have to. They live with danger and the unknown. These people are different. They are not like most of us. We like our safe world with microwaves and phones. We do not understand why they take risks.
**Sailing**
Jonathan Raban is a writer who is afraid of the sea. But he spends a lot of time sailing. He is not the best sailor, but he is good. He sails because he likes to write about it. His boat has a device that tells him where he is. He likes this device. But he thinks the compass changed how people sail. Before the compass, sailors watched the sea and waves. Now, they just look at the compass. The sea is now just a space to cross. Raban has time to look at the waves because his boat can steer itself.

**Holiday Reading**
Summer is a time for two happy things: going on holiday and reading books. These two things go well together. Books help us feel good in the world. We can see our own lives in the stories of books. Books show us our thoughts and feelings. They say things we feel but cannot say. This is special, especially if the book is from a far place or a long time ago. We thank these writers for helping us know ourselves. 
When we travel and read, we see new things. Our eyes are open in a new place, just like when we read a good book. We notice things we did not see before. We see the sky, people's faces, and our feelings. 
**Author's Note**
These travel stories were in a newspaper called the Observer. I made some small changes, but not many. Sometimes I fixed mistakes. In one story about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but it did not. I did not change the story because it was true at that time. 
Travel is about seeing the world, even if we do not know everything. We learn as we go. 
**Ecotourism**
Ecotourism is a word used a lot. It started in the 1980s. People wanted to travel without hurting the environment. Now, many trips are called ecotourism. It can mean living with tribes or a short boat trip. The idea was good, but now it is used for many things. 
**Transylvanian Journey**
I lost my notes from my trip to Transylvania for 50 years. I found them again by luck. They helped me remember my trip. In Transylvania, I stayed in nice houses for a long time. I did not write much then because I thought there was nothing to say. Later, I wrote my book and let the story tell itself.

**Music and the Future**
Technology is changing how we live and enjoy music. In the past, people listened to music on the radio, TV, and CDs. Now, there are many new ways to listen to music. Because of this, there are fewer live music shows and jobs for musicians.
Music is important for everyone. It is part of big events and personal activities. In the future, music will still be important, but it might change. People might still want to learn to play instruments. Playing music can help people learn other skills, like being on time and working well with others.
In the future, people might listen to many different kinds of music. Technology will help people make music, even if they do not know how to play an instrument. More people might want to make music in their communities.
To prepare for the future, music teachers need to change how they teach. They should help more people learn to play instruments. Music teachers will need to be good at working with many people and teaching different skills.
Music is important in our lives, and we should not forget that. People who work in music need to show how important music is.

**The Actor's Craft**
Sometimes people make fun of actors. This happens when actors talk too much about their work in interviews. They should be like the dancer Pavlova. When someone asked her what her dance meant, she said, "If I could tell you, I wouldn't dance it." Actors often use big words or talk about gossip. Paul Scofield, a famous actor, said that acting is only interesting when you do it, not when you talk about it. Every play is new for an actor, and they learn each time. When a play ends, the actor feels empty until the next one.
**A Review of Hamlet**
Adrian Lester plays Hamlet. He is between being a boy and a man. His acting is simple and strong. He is very good with the words and his body. He is smart and confident. Lester plays a young man who is a bit angry but also funny. He is both strong and nice. His acting is very good. When you watch him, you see how he moves and acts. It makes you think about what acting is and what real behavior is.
**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**
This director has a special way to practice plays. The stage manager shows the script on a screen. Actors sit and listen. When it's their turn, they read the words, think about them, and then speak. They imagine a scene, like waiting in the rain. They find a reason to say the words. The director says to keep an open mind and trust that something will happen.
**The Perfect Theatre**
A perfect theatre makes you feel important. Going to a play is special. The staff should make you feel welcome. The theatre should connect the actors and the audience. Everyone should see and hear well. The theatre should fit the human voice and body. Old theatres often have a good design. They feel like they have history. Plays should surprise you. You want to see something new and exciting.

**Paul Simon and Rock and Roll**
In the 1950s, rock and roll music was very popular with young people. It was important because it changed how many people, including older ones, thought about music. This music helped new rock stars to become famous. Paul Simon, a young boy in the US, loved this new music. He listened to it on the radio show called Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party by Alan Freed. Many young people listened to this show. Paul Simon, like John Lennon in England, was excited by the music. He wanted to make his own music.
**Snow Adventure**
I could not see a path, but I thought I would be okay if I was careful. The wind was strong and pushed me down as I walked on the ice. Suddenly, the snow under me broke, and I fell into a hole. The hole was about four feet deep. The snow had covered a space between two rocks. I climbed out, feeling scared. I sat by a pine tree to think. I had walked half a mile in one hour. I knew I had to stop my plan.
**Qualitative Research**
There are many books about qualitative research. These books talk a lot about collecting data but not much about how to look at the data. Many people do not know how researchers study their data. We asked some social scientists to talk about how they do it. We wanted to understand the process better, not just make a guidebook. This is not easy, so we let them share their work in different ways, like telling personal stories or using formal writing.

**Screen Learning**
A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was using his teeth and trying to look like a dinosaur. He said, "I'm a little dinosaur." He was copying a TV show. I asked him what he knew about dinosaurs. He didn't know much. Many people like learning on the internet and computers, but is it good? One dad tried a computer program with his son. The dad read the words, but the son played with the pictures. The dad said, "If he read a book for ten minutes, he might learn something." TV shows, like my son's, give ideas but not much learning. Learning is better with teachers or parents talking. New technology is good, but schools are still important.
**Hollywood**
By 1918, most movies were made in Hollywood. People in Los Angeles didn't like it at first. But they liked success. Success means making money from movies. Hollywood knows a good movie when it makes a lot of money. In less than 100 years, Hollywood became famous like New York, Rome, or Paris. It changed a lot. A long time ago, there were orange trees. Now, it is a busy place. People in Hollywood talk about movies, who is dating, and who is working on new projects. Successful people sometimes leave, but many people in show-business come to Hollywood.
**Photography**
Photography was made by artists in the 1800s. They wanted to keep pictures of what they saw. They used light, lenses, and chemicals to make pictures. These pictures were better than paintings. Some artists didn't like this new way. They said photography was not art. But photographers knew it was a new art. They used cameras like artists use brushes. They showed the world and people in it.
**Book Illustration**
In the past, all children's books had pictures. Even books for older kids had pictures. Many children's books were made, but not all were good. Some were great. The old black-and-white pictures are like a mix of junk and treasure. Some pictures will be shown again in new books or exhibitions. People are starting to like these old pictures again. Maybe a publisher will make new books with these classic pictures.

'Blogging: Sharing with the World Some time ago, a website talked about the risks of telling everyone where you are online. It said that when you say, 'Hey, I'm here,' you are also telling everyone, even people you don't know. This shows that sharing too much online can be bad. The internet lets us share everything about our lives with many people. We think we might get rich or famous, so we share our stories and photos online. But sometimes, we share too much and it can be dangerous. This can be sad, but don't worry. Some people have already learned about these problems. A long time ago, some people started sharing their lives online. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and became famous before social media was popular. These people were the first bloggers. They learned lessons that can help us today. In 1994, a student named Justin Hall started sharing his life online. He wrote about everything and shared photos. Many people read his blog. But one day, he had to stop because it caused problems in his life. He learned that sharing too much can make people not trust you. In 2002, Heather Armstrong wrote a blog about her job. Someone at her work shared her blog with her bosses, and she lost her job. This shows that what we say online can affect our real lives. But Heather's story ended well. She got married, started her blog again, and now writes about her family. She learned to share carefully online. We should remember that we can say anything online, but it doesn't mean we should.'

'Do You Get Enough Sleep? Many people today feel tired. In busy countries, people often do not sleep well. In the USA, 40 million people have sleep problems. Some books in Britain talk about people who cannot sleep. People are interested in sleep. They want to know how much sleep they need. One sleep expert says, 'People need more sleep. They wake up early to go to work.' A sleep researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep for 14 hours a night for a month. After three weeks, they slept about eight hours a night. This shows they needed more sleep before. In Europe, a university in England studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, noise affects sleep, and driving when tired. They ask students to help with their research. Students get paid and change their sleep for the study. Dr. Louise Reyner says some people worry because they put things on their heads to study sleep. But they only look at physical things. In a dark room, there is a car simulator. People come at 2 pm after little or no sleep. They drive and answer questions. The road looks long, and the sun is bright. The air is warm. People say they will not sleep, but they do. Dr. Reyner has a video of someone trying not to sleep. At first, he is awake, but then he blinks and nods off. Coffee can help. Two cups can make you a safe driver for 30 minutes. Dr. Reyner suggests coffee, energy drinks, and gum for alertness. Shift workers can use them. We know people sleep in cycles like other animals. There are four stages of sleep. Dreams happen in light sleep. The brain stops the body from moving to prevent injury. Scientists know women sleep 30 minutes more than men, and older people need less sleep. In the past, people had different sleep patterns. Between 1500 and 1850, people in Britain slept in two parts. They went to bed at nine or ten, woke up after midnight, stayed awake for an hour, and then slept again. This time was quiet and good for thinking. Poor people liked this time because they were free from work. In the 17th century, with more light, rich people started sleeping like we do now. The industrial revolution made people work longer, so they slept less. In some places outside Europe and America, people still sleep in parts. They sleep for a few hours, wake up, and then sleep again. In some tribal societies, noise and danger make it hard to sleep all night. People everywhere need more sleep.'

'I was wearing very expensive cowboy boots in the Arizona desert. I wanted to look like a cowboy, but I was not a cowboy. I came from Denver and thought I might look like a cowboy from the sky. But at the airport, a real cowboy saw my new boots and just walked away. I used to be a racing driver. I loved driving fast cars. But now I don't drive anymore. **Family Business**
"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were in the car going back to London. My father and my brother Maurice had just picked me up from my school. I had won two prizes at school: one for Latin and one for doing well in exams. My father talked to my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.
"What isn't good?" I asked, but I knew what he was thinking. My father usually talked a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "You have all those certificates. I heard you will get a scholarship to Oxford."
"So?" I said. "Mightn't that be useful?"
"I also heard," he continued, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister of all things!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law.
"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"
"And they say you have the right personality - you can understand things quickly, you talk well, and you like performing."
"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see on TV."
"Anyway," he said, "I think you won't want to join the family business now. You'll go to Oxford, and after that, you won't want it."
Like many children, I felt trapped by family expectations. I wanted to try different jobs, but I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't scared of him like Maurice was, but I found him strong.
"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.
"I tell you, you won't want to join us," my father said. "It's a pity because you have the brains, the nerves, the vision."
"There's still Maurice," I said, unhappy. My father snorted. We both knew Maurice hated the business.
"You could always use me as a consultant," I said. My mother wasn't around to help - she died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger, and I took care of him. I loved Maurice.
Because the business was successful, we lived well - a big house in London, good schools, nice clothes, parties, theatres, operas. My father knew many people - politicians, actors, businessmen - and our house was always lively.
"You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford," my father said. "Then, if you want to leave, you can. It will give you some pocket money and help me."
"OK," I said, happy to avoid making a decision now. My father controlled us this way.
So it happened. In my last school term and during university vacations, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always on easy tasks. I became a smart student, with a little house, a small white car, designer clothes, and a black dress from Paris for my final exams.
In my last term, my father visited me. He took me to a village for a meal and a chat. My tutor said I might get a First Class degree in Law. I felt confident.
But my father needed me for one last job. It was the most important work the family firm ever had. "But Dad," I said, "I have my final exams soon. I need to focus on them."
I could see my father didn't understand my pressure. He might think I was betraying him if I said no. As he talked, I saw how focused and smart he was. He was a kind of genius, and I respected that. It made my plans seem less important.
"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

'Flying Without Gravity Journalist Tom Mumford joins students testing ideas in weightlessness. The plane looked normal from the outside. The pilot told the young passengers it was a Boeing KC-135, made in 1964. But inside, it was different. It was a long white tunnel with lights on the walls. There were few seats, and 13 students from Europe and America sat at the back. They had worked hard for a year to be on this flight. The European Space Agency asked students to think of experiments to do in weightlessness. The best ideas won a place on this special flight. The plane flew up and down like a roller-coaster. At the top of each curve, the plane and everything inside became weightless for a few seconds. The students felt like they were closer to the moon than the Earth. The plane took off smoothly, but soon it climbed steeply. The engines were loud, and we felt strange. Then the engines stopped, and we floated. For 20 seconds, we moved in silence. We could not tell up from down. After 10 seconds of falling, the pilot made the plane fly level again. Gravity came back, and some students fell. There were 30 curves in total, giving 10 minutes of weightlessness for experiments. Dutch students studied a robotic cat to see how cats land on their feet. A German team looked at how metal joins in space. Students from Utah State University tried to make solar sails from thin films. They hope these sails can use the sun's light like a yacht uses the wind. After two hours, we felt a bit sick, but mostly excited. One student said, 'It was unforgettable. I want to be an astronaut even more now.''

**My Trees in New Zealand**
I am Jonathon Porritt. I wrote a book called "Seeing Green." I love winter. I went to New Zealand every summer, which is winter there. I had nine winters in a row. My parents bought land in New Zealand for me, my brother, and my sister. We could have it if we planted trees. The land is near Auckland, in a place called Rangitoupuni. It is not great land, but good for trees. I like land and farming. I worked in Australia on farms before. 
We started planting trees in 1968. By 1972, we planted all 70 acres. It rained a lot, but I was happy. Every morning, we got ready to plant. It was cold and wet. I had help from a man who knew how to plant trees. We used a planting bag for the trees. Planting was hard work, but I liked it. We had to make straight lines for the trees. I got used to the work and found a rhythm. 
While planting, I thought a lot about life and nature. I went back to New Zealand four times to see the trees grow. I worry about storms and droughts there. The trees are now 20 years old and doing well. 
In 1984, I took time off from teaching and went back alone. I wrote my first book there. I stayed in a small cabin. I wrote in the morning, pruned trees in the afternoon, and did research in the evening. I feel a strong connection to that place. It is special to me.

Title: Taking Care of Badgers
One day, someone gave me a box. Inside, I found three small badger babies. They were grey and had black-and-white stripes on their heads. They were cold and needed help. 
My husband Derek and I have a farm in Somerset. We help animals that have no parents. The badger babies came from a place where workers found them. Their mother was dead, and the babies were hungry.
I took the badgers into my kitchen to keep them warm. There were two girls, Primrose and Bluebell, and one boy, Willow. I fed them with a bottle. They needed to eat every four hours. 
After a few days, the badgers started to move around. But one day, Willow got sick and died. I was sad, but I kept taking care of the other two.
Later, a farmer brought me another boy badger. We called him Willow II. He was hard to feed, but he learned to eat sausages. 
The badgers grew up and started eating different foods like cereals, meat, and vegetables. They liked to play and go for walks at night. 
We built a special home for the badgers on our farm. It had tunnels and rooms for them to sleep in. Many people helped us build it. 
Now, the badgers live in their new home. They are happy and safe. Sometimes, they come to say hello before going out at night. This is their home now.

'Looking for True North - and the Man Behind Halley's Comet Dr. Toby Clark works at the British Geological Survey. He wants to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to study compass changes. Anjana Ahuja tells us more. Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for Halley's Comet. But he also did important work with compasses. He found out how compasses change direction. This is called 'declination'. It is the angle between magnetic north and true north. Sailors need this to use their compasses correctly. Without it, they could not find their way on the ocean. Halley was one of two men paid to do science in his time. He sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to study declination. The trip stopped early because of problems with the crew. But Halley tried again. He sailed to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. In 1701, he made a map showing compass changes in the ocean. This map helped sailors for over 100 years. Now, Dr. Clark wants to celebrate Halley's work. He plans to sail the same route as Halley. He needs to raise Â£70,000 for the trip. Sir Vivian Fuchs, a famous explorer, is helping him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working in Antarctica. He read about Halley's life. Halley was a great scientist and explorer. He also helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book. Dr. Clark's trip will also have scientific value. He will take new measurements of the magnetic field. This will help update the Earth's magnetic field model. The British Geological Survey and the U.S. Navy will give him tools. A Danish satellite will also take similar measurements. Dr. Clark hopes his work will fill in any missing data. Halley's journey was the first big science trip on the sea. He was the first civilian naval captain for science. Dr. Clark has the experience for this trip. He worked in Antarctica and sailed from Rio to England. The trip will have four parts with different crews. Dr. Clark is ready to spend eight months on this project. He says Halley's life gives him a strong purpose.'

**Peacocks and Their Beautiful Tails**
Every summer, peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show their big, colorful tails. The female peacocks, called hens, look at these tails. A long time ago, a man named Charles Darwin wondered why peacocks have such big tails. He thought animals survive by being strong and smart. But peacocks have big tails that seem to make life harder.
Darwin had an idea called "sexual selection." He thought hens liked beautiful tails. Another man, Alfred Russel Wallace, thought the tails showed something important about the peacock, like being healthy.
Today, scientists like Marion Petrie study peacocks at Whipsnade. They want to know if hens really like the peacocks with the biggest tails. They also want to know if these peacocks are better in other ways, like being healthier.
Some people think peacocks with big tails have fewer parasites, which are tiny creatures that can make them sick. But scientists have not checked this yet.
This year, Dr. Petrie is looking at the babies of peacocks with big tails and those with small tails. She wants to see if the babies of peacocks with big tails grow faster and are healthier.
A long time ago, a man named R A Fisher had an idea called "Fisher's Runaway." He thought if hens liked big tails, then over time, peacocks would have bigger and bigger tails. This idea means hens might choose peacocks just because they look nice, like Darwin thought.

**Natural Talents**
Humans and chimpanzees are very similar. We are more than 98% the same in our genes. This means we are not very different from animals. Many things we thought only humans could do, animals can do too. For example, chimpanzees use sticks as tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple sounds for danger, like "leopard" or "snake."
Art is something special for humans. But our early ancestors did not make art for a long time. The first clear human art is from about 35,000 years ago. This includes cave paintings and statues.
People say human art is different because:
1. It is not useful for survival.
2. It is made for beauty.
3. It is learned, not instinctive.
Human art does not help us live or have children. Birds sing to find a mate, but humans make art for fun or to share feelings. Human art styles change quickly, and people learn them. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn both.
Some animals, like birds, are born knowing their songs. But humans learn art from others. Art changes fast, like how paintings from 100 years ago look different from today.
Chimpanzees Congo and Betsy made paintings too. They painted for fun, not to survive. Their art was shown in a London gallery in 1957, and people bought their paintings. This shows that animal art can be like human art. But human artists often want to share their art with others, while the chimpanzees did not.

'Why do we sleep? People sleep for about one-third of their lives. Sleep is very important, but scientists are not sure why. There are three main ideas about why we sleep. The first idea says sleep helps our body stay healthy. When we sleep, our body fixes itself and gets ready for the next day. The second idea says sleep helps us learn. **Eccentrics**
An eccentric is a person who acts differently from others. They do not follow what most people do. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Many people have small, strange habits. Some like to enter newspaper contests, collect beer mats, or write letters to newspapers about many topics. Being eccentric means being unique.
Inside us, we have two feelings. One wants us to be different, and the other wants us to be like everyone else. Most people want to be accepted and loved, so they choose to be like others. People with unusual hobbies or ideas often find others like them. They make clubs and have meetings to talk about their interests. They feel better when they are with others who understand them.
Sometimes, we want to show we are different. We might say, "I say what I think," or "You must take me as I am." We can choose to be different and show our personality. Some people become famous by doing this, like Bob Dylan, a singer. He said, "When you know what you want and go for it, people might not understand you."
But being different on purpose is not the same as being eccentric. If a singer wears strange clothes to get attention, or a person says shocking things to be noticed, they are not eccentric. They are only eccentric if they keep doing these things naturally, without thinking about it.
True eccentrics do not try to be strange; they just are. They do not care what others think. They do things because it is who they are. This makes them different from people who want to impress or escape from society. Eccentrics live their lives without worrying about what others think.

Title: Do Reviews Help Sell Books?
We asked five important British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said:
Publisher A: Reviews are very important for selling books. Many people buy books because of reviews. Both authors and publishers feel sad if there are no reviews. But publishers think any review, good or bad, can help sell books. They like reviews that agree with their own thoughts about the book.
Publisher B: Publishers and newspapers both like book reviews, but they want different things. Newspapers want to entertain readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed positively. Reviews are better now than 40 years ago. Paperbacks often do not get enough attention. Reviews help people know about books and can increase sales.
Publisher C: Reviews are very important for us. We do not have famous authors, so we need reviews to help sell our books. Good reviews are better than advertisements. They help readers trust the book. Reviews can help a book become popular, but they need help from other things like word-of-mouth and good marketing.
Publisher D: In the US, one review can make a book popular. In Britain, it is different. Sometimes, it takes many years for people to notice a good book. Some books sell well even without good reviews. Non-fiction reviews often talk more about the subject than the book.
Publisher E: Publishers and writers want good reviews. But sometimes, if reviews are too detailed, people do not buy the book because they feel they already know it. The reviewer's name used to matter more. Now, it is more about how interesting or funny the review is.

But Graham's first weathervane was a witch on a broomstick. He made it as a surprise gift for his wife. Friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. Title: Beginner Wins Big
Before it was published, "The Horse Whisperer" was a very popular book. It is the first book by British writer Nicholas Evans. He made a lot of money from it. Here, he talks about his ideas and success.
At the start of the year, things were not good for Nicholas Evans. He is a writer and producer. A movie he was working on stopped suddenly. He was worried because he had not made money for two years. The bank was also unhappy with him. 
Instead of getting a job, Evans decided to write a book. He went to America for three months to learn more for his book. He got the idea from a man he met in Dartmoor. The man told him about a horse that changed after a gypsy talked to it. These people are called "horse whisperers."
Evans wanted to write a movie script but decided to write a book instead. He traveled in the US, learning about horses and the people who work with them. He felt alone and worried about money. 
By August, he wrote half of the book. He showed it to a friend who said it was "fine." The friend thought Evans might get $30,000 for it. Evans needed more money to pay his debts. He wrote a summary of the rest of the book.
In October, the book was sent to publishers. Soon, his agent got an offer of $75,000. Evans was surprised. In a week, the book was sold for a lot of money in the UK and the US. It was a record for a first book. 
Hollywood also wanted the book. Evans got $3 million for the movie rights. He was very surprised. He did not want to write the movie script because he wanted to stay in control. 
Evans now thinks he should write another book.

'Choosing a Clock Radio Stuart Harris reports Many people use a radio to wake up in the morning. A clock radio helps us get out of bed. But how do you choose a good one? Our team, including me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five clock radios. One model has a 'dual alarm function'. **Shopping Tricks**
Have you ever gone to a store and bought more than you wanted? Stores use tricks to make you buy more. Here are some of them:
**A. Fresh Look**
Supermarkets know people like fresh food. They put fruits and vegetables at the front of the store. They might also have a bakery with the smell of fresh bread. The store might use green colors because green means fresh. Most things in the store, like frozen food, are not fresh.
**B. Good Display**
Where things are in the store is important. Supermarkets know where people look the most. They put expensive or fast-selling things there. Shelves at eye level are the best for selling. Special offers are in big bins. They also put things that go together, like salad dressing near salads.
**C. Spread Out**
Supermarkets put cheap things like bread and tea far from the entrance. You have to walk past other things that might tempt you. Stores put popular items far away so you see other things on the way.
**D. Less is More**
Some stores show fewer items to look special. Next stores do this. They make clothes look exclusive, but they are not. Itâ€™s about good store design.
**E. Total Price**
People care more about the total bill than each itemâ€™s price. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items. They might sell some things cheap to get you in the store. They buy in big amounts to get discounts.
**F. Price Tags**
In chain stores, people notice prices more. Pricing something at $14.99 instead of $15 makes a difference. It also helps stop theft because staff have to give change.
**G. Lighting**
Stores use special lights. Chain stores want natural light so clothes look the same outside. Supermarkets use lights to make food look better.
**H. Walking Paths**
Stores use different carpets to guide you. Some paths lead you through the store. Marks and Spencer use wood or marble for paths and carpet for sales areas.
**I. In-Store Ads**
When you enter a supermarket, you see big pictures of food. In the US, some trolleys have screens that show ads. These ads change as you move through the store. They make people buy more.

**A Simple History of the Apple**
**Old Apples**  
People have eaten apples for a very long time. In ancient times, people in places like Switzerland and Italy ate small wild apples. These apples were not like the ones we eat today.
**Apples in Britain**  
Around 1000 AD, the French learned how to grow good apples from the Romans. They brought this knowledge to Britain. British monks worked on making new kinds of apples. These apples are the ancestors of many apples we have now.
**Popular Apples**  
In the 1200s, some apples became popular in Britain. One was the Old English Pearmain, which looked like a pear. Another was the Costard, used for cooking. But then, fewer apples were grown because of problems like droughts and wars. In the 1500s, King Henry VIII sent a man to France to learn more about apples. He brought back new apple types and started a big apple farm in Kent.
**Apples Around the World**  
By the 1700s, apples were very popular in Britain. People took apples with them when they moved to places like Canada, the US, Australia, and South Africa. A man named Johnny Appleseed planted many apple trees in America.
**New Apples**  
In the 1800s, new apples were discovered. In Iowa, a farmer found a new apple and called it 'Delicious'. In Australia, a woman named Maria Smith found a new green apple. It became known as the 'Granny Smith' apple.
**Apples Today**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world. Most apples come from just a few types. People want more different kinds of apples. It is important to keep many types of apples alive for everyone to enjoy.

**Mass Marketing and Advertising**
Advertising is having problems. It is not just because of the bad economy. Advertising started to go down in 1989, before the economy got worse. The problem is bigger and is happening everywhere. Advertising has not changed with the times. Advertisers think about big markets and big media, but now there are many brands and media. This means markets are smaller. Big brands should focus on small groups, but they often do not. This is where advertising is going wrong.
Think about when you shop. You might buy 30 to 50 things at the supermarket. Many of these are not advertised brands. You might buy a few advertised brands from the 15,000 items in the store. In a year, you might buy a few hundred brands. Big items like cars? Maybe one every three years. Clothes? Not many are advertised brands. Even with candy, medicine, and services, you probably buy less than 400 brands a year.
There are 32,500 advertised brands, but most people only buy 400. This means a lot of advertising is wasted. When you watch TV, count how many ads are for things you buy. For most people, it is about 1 in 16 ads. This means 15 out of 16 ads are wasted.
People think they do not pay attention to ads, but everyone sees them. Most people do not buy the brands they see. Waste is part of advertising. Not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. But advertising still works because it reaches many people. Advertisers do not know who will buy, so they show ads to many people.
Smart targeting can help reduce waste. Advertisers can try to reach the right people, but they can never be sure who will respond. Even direct mail does not get a 100% response. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might sell to everyone they talk to.
If an advertiser gets one million new customers, it is very good. For soap powder, the top brands would be happy with a million new customers. An ad campaign that gets 2% of people to buy is very successful. This is a small part of the population. To succeed, advertising needs to focus more on the right people.

'THE DAY I STOPPED SMOKING I thought everyone would be happy, but one of my friends was very angry. 'Why didn't you stop years ago if it was so easy?' she asked. I couldn't explain how I went from smoking every day to not smoking in just four hours. It was strange to me too. I went to a stop-smoking session with a group and a therapist. This happened two months and three weeks ago. I didn't plan to stop smoking, and I didn't really want to. I didn't like the pressure from people who don't like smoking. I was healthy and didn't feel sick. I went to the session in Birmingham to write an article about people trying to stop smoking. I said, 'I won't try to stop. I'm here to write, not to stop smoking.' I liked smoking. It made me happy. The therapist looked at me like he knew something. We could smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was full of smoke. But when they told us to smoke, I didn't want to, and others didn't either. The idea of stopping smoking started to make sense. It felt good to think about not being a smoker. It was a secret feeling just for me. Could I do more things too? Stopping was not too hard. The need for nicotine went away after a few days. I thought working without smoking would be hard, but it wasn't. Being at home on weekends was the hardest. Smoking was something to do when I was bored. I miss smoking, but not too much. Doing things without smoking, like eating out or waiting for a plane, is new for me.'

Margaret and Her Special Skill
Margaret Wilkins has a special skill. She can find water underground using a forked stick. Many farmers ask for her help when their wells are dry. Margaret and her husband have a business to drill wells. They use machines, but to find water, Margaret only needs her stick. They are successful more than 90% of the time.
This skill is called dowsing. Some people think it is like a 'sixth sense'. There are different ideas about how it works. Some say it is because everything vibrates, and water vibrates more. Dowsers, like Margaret, can feel these vibrations. Some say they can even smell water.
Margaret is very busy, especially when there is little rain. Many of her customers are farmers. Others have holiday homes or golf courses. Margaret looks for water 50 to 70 meters deep. She makes sure the water is clean and not near waste. The well also needs to be close to electricity for the pump.
Margaret starts by looking at a map with a pendulum. The pendulum swings over places with water. Then, she walks with her stick to find the exact spot. When she is over water, she feels something special. The stick moves up when water is below. It is important to drill exactly where the stick shows.
Margaret and her husband both check the spot. If they do not agree, they keep looking. Margaret's skill is not common, but it helps her family business. She calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment'. This skill helps her find water and keep their business going.

This is a famous Western movie. It has been made to look and sound better. The music is very exciting. The story is about three men who are not very nice, but it is fun to watch.

This is a long war movie with many actors. It shows soldiers waiting for a big battle. The movie is impressive but is better to watch on a big screen. On video, it is not as good.
