Tim Pozzi is 34 years old. He left his job to go backpacking. He wants to travel in South East Asia for one year. Tim is a little scared. He traveled before, after university, in North and South America. But then he got a job, fell in love, and bought a house. Now, he wants to feel free again. Many of his friends have families, but Tim is not in a relationship and has no big career plans. He wants to enjoy his freedom.
Tim is nervous about renting his house and planning his trip. He is also worried about living simply and meeting young backpackers. But many people in their late twenties and thirties want to travel. They want adventure and to take a break from their jobs. Danny, 30, and his girlfriend Tammy, 28, are traveling for a year before settling down. Matt, who was in the Army, traveled to change his way of thinking.
Today, more people have short-term jobs, so they can travel when their job ends. Some companies let people take a break and come back later. Many people in their thirties think about their lives and want to try something new. Travel helps them think about what they really want.
Ben, 32, is going to Central America for a year. He is not running away; he wants to find something new. He will miss his daily routine, but he is excited. Tim feels the same. He is excited about the next year and happy to try something different.

'Georgina McGuiness stopped working in journalism for a long time. She felt she did not know much about new technology. She tells us how she changed her home to work better. Two years ago, at Christmas, she turned 37. She thought it was time to start her career again. Her old skills were from the 1980s, using a typewriter. She did not know how to use a computer. Many jobs wanted people who knew desktop publishing, but she did not. She was afraid of technology, even simple things like calculators. She thought it would be hard to work again before her children grew up. Then, she entered a competition in a newspaper and won a computer package. Her family got a laptop and a personal computer. They learned new words like Internet and surfing. They talked to people online from around the world. The children stopped watching TV, and Georgina made a small office in the kitchen. She had a phone, fax machine, CD-ROM, and modem. She could work from home and still take her children to school. The children were good with computers because they learned at school. Georgina was scared she would lose her work if she pressed the wrong button. But she learned the basic skills she needed. It was easy and made sense. She started writing for a magazine, two articles a month. She was happy she could work and be with her family. The computer helped her be organized. She used spreadsheets to keep track of money. She could find information online and talk to other journalists. But working from home can be lonely. There are distractions, like housework and sharing the computer with her children. Many people now have computers at home. They like not having to travel to work. A report says the average computer user is 38 years old and well-educated. Most have a personal computer, and many have a CD-ROM and modem. Georgina feels she is doing well. She hopes to send her work to newspapers or start her own magazine from home. The possibilities are endless.'

'The Tartan Museum The new Museum of Scotland is in Edinburgh. It has big, yellow buildings that look like cheese. Some people like the buildings, and some do not. Inside the museum, there are many old and special things to see. You can see things like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels. The museum tells many stories about Scotland. Dr. David Clarke, who works at the museum, says it is for everyone, not just experts. He wants people to enjoy their visit. The museum does not have fake scenes from the past. It shows real things with information panels and some computers. Inside, the museum has many rooms with big windows. There is a special place for children to play and learn. On the top floor, there is a gallery with things from the 20th century, like electric guitars and TVs. People in Scotland chose these items. Dr. Clarke believes that seeing real objects helps people understand the past. The museum's modern buildings look nice inside, but some people are not sure if they fit in Edinburgh.'

'The end of print newspapers might take a long time. Change can be scary for some people. But change can also be good. Newspapers are changing to online. This change is not easy. Many people think print newspapers will stop because more people read news online. Print newspaper sales are going down. But their websites have more visitors. This is true in some places. But in other places, print is still strong. For example, in Asia, more people are buying newspapers. Magazines are also doing well. They sold more last year. Books are interesting too. E-readers like Kindle are popular. But people still buy paper books. Both are important. Young people still read newspapers. In the UK, fewer people buy newspapers. But in Germany and France, the drop is smaller. Different countries have different stories. Online ads were supposed to help newspapers. But now, online ads are not making as much money. Many US newspapers ask people to pay to read online. They also sell print and online together. Print is important for selling online news. Print ads make more money than online ads. This is hard for newspapers because they need to do both print and online. But print is still important for newspapers.'

**Taking Photos of People**
People are very interesting to take photos of. A photo with a person is usually more interesting than one without. But, taking good photos of people can be hard. You need to think about how they move and their faces. Sometimes, people act differently when they see a camera.
**A. Group Photos**
When taking photos of a group, don't make them stand in a straight line. Ask them to stand in different ways. Some can sit or kneel in front so you can see all faces.
**B. Posing for Photos**
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax. Tell them to fold their hands or put them in their pockets.
**C. Taking Photos**
Don't pretend you are not taking a photo. Most people will say yes if you ask. They might feel shy, so you can help them by telling them what to do.
**D. Eye Contact**
A photo is better if the person looks at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens. They don't have to smile. You can say something funny to make them relax.
**E. Looking at Something**
Instead of looking at the camera, the person can look at something else in the photo. This can make the photo interesting.
**F. Expressions and Gestures**
Faces and hands tell a lot about a person. A smiling child makes us happy. A sad face makes us feel sad too. Look for common expressions like a thumbs-up or a wink.
**G. Backgrounds**
The background can make a photo more interesting. Make sure the background is not too busy. Use a wide lens to make the person look bigger than the background.
**H. Interaction**
Photos of people talking or playing together are nice. Look for eye contact or a friendly touch, like a hand on the arm.
**I. People and Places**
Many photos are taken on trips. To show people and the place, use a wide lens. Ask people to stand close to the camera. Make sure you can see both the people and the place.
**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**
Think about why you want the photo. If you want to remember someone, ask them to pose. For family photos, candid shots are more fun. They show real moments and memories.

'Sarah's Art Sarah Janson is an artist. She makes paintings that look very real. These paintings trick your eyes. Sarah does not like to talk about herself. She thinks her art is more important. Sarah has been making these paintings for sixteen years. She learned to draw at art school. She also worked at a publishing house. But she wanted to do something different. She started working with a decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to make a special painting. She loved it and decided to do it on her own. Sarah is very good at looking at details. She says you learn this art by looking at things in life. Sarah sometimes finds it hard to talk about her skills. She jokes that she cannot paint bread well. Sarah has made many paintings for big companies and private people. Her work is inspired by buildings. One painting looks like a room you can walk into. Sarah says her art must trick you and make you think. She likes to work with clients to get ideas. Many clients become her friends. Sarah is busy because people like her work. She does not like to talk loudly about her talent. But her work is very special and deserves to be known.'

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**
**A** The way we work is changing. It's not just about being smart or having good training. It's also about how we handle ourselves and others. This is called emotional intelligence. It helps decide who gets a job and who does well at work. Emotional intelligence is about social skills and personal qualities like being able to understand others and adapt to change.
**B** Today, job security is not guaranteed. So, personal qualities are important. Emotional intelligence means knowing and controlling our own and others' feelings. It helps us work well with others. It's not just about being nice. Sometimes, it means telling the truth even if it's hard. Emotional intelligence helps us express feelings in the right way.
**C** Many businesses now see emotional intelligence as important. It helps people work together better. Jobs are more complex, and teamwork is important. Emotional intelligence is needed for success in every job.
**D** Unlike IQ, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from life. We can get better at understanding and controlling our emotions. This growth is called maturity. We can learn emotional intelligence skills to help us in life and work. It is not a magic solution, but it is important for success.

'Should the media make money from things they don't own? Today, many people use digital cameras and phones to take pictures of important events. Social media has changed how we share these pictures. Now, some journalists use social media to find pictures for news stories. Sometimes, they use these pictures without asking. There are rules that say it's okay to use pictures without asking if it's very important for the public. But people still talk about whether this is right or wrong. Research shows that about one in ten people would take pictures or videos of a news event. This means these pictures are important for the media. But, to keep a good relationship with people, the media should make sure to ask for permission and give rewards for these pictures.'

Acupuncture is a very old treatment from China. It is 2,000 years old. Acupuncture is part of Chinese medicine. Chinese medicine also uses herbs, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture helps with pain. Some doctors and nurses use it to help people with pain.
In Chinese medicine, health means the body and mind are in balance. Energy, called Qi (say "chee"), moves in the body. It moves along lines called meridians. There are twelve main meridians. Each one is linked to an organ. If Qi is blocked, the body can get sick. An acupuncturist checks your wrist pulse, looks at your tongue, and asks about your health. They use small needles on the skin to help Qi flow.
There are over 300 points for acupuncture. The points are on the meridians. The needle can make a dull ache or tingling feeling. This means the needle reached the Qi. Doctors think acupuncture helps with pain because it blocks pain signals or releases natural painkillers.
Acupuncture can help with back pain, headaches, and other pains. It is also used in surgery in China. It helps with pain during operations. Acupuncture does not have the side effects of regular pain medicine.
Not everyone feels better with acupuncture. But many people do. It can take six or seven visits to feel better. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the pain. They ask about the weather and how it affects the pain.
Some doctors use traditional acupuncture. Others use scientific ideas. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist. They should send you to a doctor if needed.

P.D. James is a famous writer from England. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She writes crime stories. People all over the world read her books. She is shy but very smart. Her detective character, Adam Dalgliesh, is a bit like her. She likes to be alone when she writes. P.D. James started writing books when she was 42 years old. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband in Cambridge. Her husband was sick after the war, so she worked hard to take care of him and their two daughters. She worked for the National Health Service and the Home Office. She saw many things in her job that helped her write crime stories. She likes to write because it helps her make sense of things. She believes solving crimes in stories shows that life is important.

'Handwriting Can Show Who You Are Some people think handwriting can show a person's character. In some countries, when you apply for a job, you might need to give a sample of your handwriting. Companies use handwriting to see if you are right for the job. This is called handwriting analysis or graphology. Some people believe it can show if someone is sick or has emotional problems. Big companies use graphologists to look at handwriting for important jobs. But many doctors do not believe in graphology. Patricia Marne is a graphologist. She has worked for more than 20 years. She thinks handwriting can show if a person is smart or what job they should do. She says it can also show if someone might be a criminal. Criminals often have messy handwriting. Ms. Marne says handwriting can show if someone is honest or a good worker. She thinks it can also show if someone is under stress or has health problems. For example, if handwriting changes a lot, it might mean something serious is happening. Ms. Marne says it takes six years to learn how to read handwriting well. She believes more research is needed to make graphology a real science. But some doctors do not agree. They think handwriting only shows how a person learned to write and does not mean anything else.'

'Is your office working well? Fresh air and good chairs are important for happy workers, says a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how good they are for working. We had three experts: a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies how people work), and an occupational psychologist. Here is what they said.
Office A: Advertising Agency
Building Health Consultant: This office is very simple. There is no central heating or air conditioning. The windows open to the street. The team of seven people is happy and works well together. They make the office feel like home.
Ergonomist: The furniture is old and does not match. Chairs are not adjustable and some are broken. But the workers have different tasks, like meeting clients and making presentations, which helps them not get tired or bored.
Occupational Psychologist: The staff like the variety of work. The office is the right size, not too big or small. It is fun and creative.
Office B: News Service
Building Health Consultant: The office is comfortable and the air is good. There is no smoking allowed.
Ergonomist: The chairs and lighting are good. The space is okay, but the layout could be better. The office is a bit boring with grey walls.
Occupational Psychologist: The walls are empty except for some posters. Staff have been there for a long time and get along well. The office could be better if desks were arranged for easier sharing of information.
Office C: Bank
Building Health Consultant: The office feels like a glass case. There are smokers and non-smokers, but the air is not bad.
Ergonomist: The office is not exciting. Desks and chairs are just okay. Some computer setups are not modern.
Occupational Psychologist: Staff support each other and use technology well. The office is busy, but the colors are a bit dull.
Office D: Newspaper
Building Health Consultant: The air conditioning is not good, and the office is dusty. There is not enough desk space.
Ergonomist: The furniture is not suitable for a modern office. Chairs are old and not adjustable.
Occupational Psychologist: The office is dirty and needs cleaning. People seem stressed and busy. The company should work more as a team.'

Chewing Gum Story
Chewing gum is very popular. People in America chew 12 million pieces every day. Chewing gum has less than ten calories. It is a food, so it must follow food rules. 
Today, gum is mostly made from man-made materials. It has pine resins and softeners to keep the taste and make it feel nice. 
A long time ago, the Greeks chewed a gum-like resin from the mastic tree. This tree grows in Greece and Turkey. Greek women liked it to clean their teeth and make their breath smell nice. 
In America, people learned from Native Americans to chew resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, people sold spruce gum in the eastern United States. This was the first chewing gum sold in America.
Modern gum started in the late 1860s. People found chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more elastic. An industry grew from this.
Today, few people still collect chicle. They work in hard conditions. They walk long distances in hot, humid forests. There are dangerous snakes and insects. The chicle fly is a problem because it lays eggs in ears and noses. 
Chicle collectors climb trees with a rope and an axe. They cut the bark to get the sap. They carry the sap to a camp and boil it to make gum bricks. Life at the camp is hard. They eat mostly maize and drink alcohol from sugar cane.
Now, companies use man-made materials to make gum. This is cheaper and meets high demand. 
Gum is good for teeth. It helps make more saliva, which protects teeth. Chewing for 20 minutes can help. 
Gum makers are always finding new flavors and textures. They use glycerine and vegetable oils. Most flavors are artificial, but some need natural help. 
In America, a large area grows mint for the two most popular gums in the world.

**Remote Hotels**
**A. India - Ghanerao Hotel, Rajasthan**  
Ghanerao Hotel is in a small village in India. The village is near the Aravalli Hills. The hotel is very old, and the Ghanerao family has lived there for 400 years. Now, Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests. The hotel is simple, and hot water comes in a bucket. This makes the hotel special.
**B. New Zealand - Hermitage Hotel, Mount Cook**  
The Hermitage Hotel is on New Zealand's South Island. It is in a beautiful place, high in the mountains. You can see it after climbing down from a glacier. The hotel is very nice and has a piano player.
**C. Mauritius - Beachcomber Paradis Hotel**  
The Paradis Hotel is on a quiet part of Mauritius. It is on a small piece of land by the sea. You can drive along the coast and see empty beaches. The hotel is big, and you can do watersports for free. There is a long private beach. In the evening, you can sit on the beach and feel far away.
**D. St Lucia - Ladera Hotel**  
The Ladera Hotel is in St Lucia. It is high up, 1,000 feet above the sea. The rooms are open and have a view of the Caribbean Sea. The hotel has old-style furniture and beds with netting.
**E. Turkey - The Splendid Hotel, Istanbul**  
The Splendid Hotel is on Buyukada, an island near Istanbul. You can get there by boat in one hour. There are no cars, only horse carriages. The hotel is white with red domes. It looks like an old hotel from France. It is a little old now but still nice.
**F. France - Chateau d'Etoges, Epernay**  
Chateau d'Etoges is in a small village in France. It is a beautiful old building with a moat and swans. The chateau has 20 different rooms. Some rooms have big beds. You can stay for a weekend with breakfast and dinner. They also give you champagne.
**G. Kenya - The Fairview Hotel, Nairobi**  
The Fairview Hotel is in Nairobi, Kenya. It is a nice hotel with gardens and good food. Many travelers stay here after a safari. Some people stay for a long time. The hotel is on a hill, away from the busy city. You can watch the sunset and have a nice dinner.
**H. Italy - Hotel Splendido, Portofino**  
Hotel Splendido is in Portofino, Italy. Many famous people have stayed here. The hotel was once a monastery. It is very beautiful. The restaurant has simple but tasty food.

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. She checks hotels to see if they are good. Christopher Middleton watched her work. Sue went to the Globe Hotel. The receptionist did not say hello to Sue. Sue said, "Very poor." The Globe Hotel has three red stars. This means it is a top hotel. But Sue was not happy. The hotel had problems. The door from the car park was not good. The corridor was long and empty. The receptionist said, "We have no record of your booking." Sue did not like the room. It was stuffy, and there was a hole in the wall. Sue told the manager, Robin Greaves, about the problems. He was sorry. There was a bad smell in the lounge. Sue said to fix the smell and not take guests there. The manager wrote notes. Sue liked Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the waitress. Dinner was good. The manager asked how to get three rosettes for food. Sue said, "Do not serve a pudding that collapses." Sue tells hotels what is wrong. She writes a report for them. Hotels pay for this. The Globe Hotel will keep its red stars. Another inspector will come in two months to check again. The manager said, "Good, we'll look forward to that."

**Seven Up: Climbing the Seven Summits**
Doug Scott is a mountain climber. He climbed the highest mountain on each continent. These are called the Seven Summits. Here is his story:
**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**
Doug and his friend Dougal climbed Mt. Everest. They stayed in a snow cave near the top. Dougal talked to someone who was not there. Doug thought it was because of low oxygen. Doug's feet were very cold. He remembered other climbers who lost fingers and toes. Doug felt calm and confident with Dougal. They reached the top together.
**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**
Mt. McKinley is a dangerous mountain. In April 1976, Doug and Dougal climbed it. They carried their own food and equipment. The air felt thin, like they were higher up. They reached the top and felt very happy.
**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**
In September 1976, Doug and Paul went to climb Mt. Kenya. But they got a free ride to Kilimanjaro. They got lost in the jungle. They found a trail and water. They climbed to the top using a different path.
**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**
In January 1992, Doug and his wife Sharu went to Aconcagua. They met a guide named Phil. They climbed with him. The weather was bad, so they took an easier path. They reached the top before dark.
**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**
In November 1992, Doug went to Antarctica. The sun was always up. It was very cold and windy. Doug and his team reached the top in 8 hours.
**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**
In 1994, Doug's team went to Elbrus. They took a cable car part of the way. They thought they reached the top, but there was more to climb. They went back to their camp at night.
**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**
Doug's team wanted to climb a new path and meet local people. They were warned about danger but went anyway. They reached the top by 11 am. Doug was very happy. He finished climbing all Seven Summits.

Penny Pratt works with flowers. She has a small shop and helps supermarkets and restaurants with flowers. She used to be a teacher. Her flower designs are simple and modern. 'The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It is made from four old houses. The hotel has new technology for staff and guests. The manager, Peter MacCann, wants staff to know guests' names. The hotel computer remembers what guests like. For example, if a guest likes certain music, it will be ready for them next time. The hotel spent a lot of money on this system, but it will help in the future. Guests can change the room temperature. They can also ask the front desk to change it more. Business guests have many things in their rooms. They have phones, a fax machine, and a video-conferencing tool. The hotel is ready for new technology. TVs and DVD players can be updated. 'Susan Shepherd is an artist. She paints flowers. Her garden has many flowers. She likes tulips and poppies. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. The garden looks nice because of the old owners. They liked gardening. Susan also has a gardener named Danny. Danny helps her. Susan paints one flower at a time. She takes flowers to her studio to paint. It can take a long time to finish a painting. Spring and early summer are busy for her. Tulips and poppies bloom then. Susan likes to watch flowers change. Tulips change shape in water. Susan liked wild flowers when she was young. She studied plants in school. Now, her garden has plants from other countries. She lets the garden grow freely. Susan is busy with art shows. She has a new gardener to help. But she still likes to work in the garden.'

Many trees fell down in the big storm in March. In the town of Brackham, two big lime trees fell in the market square. This changed how the town looked, and some people did not like it. One of these people was Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham. He is the head of the local police. But during the storm, Pelham was very sick with bronchitis. He had a headache and chest pain. His wife, Molly, wanted him to see a doctor, but he did not listen. He thought the police needed him. This made him forget things and get angry easily. 
Sergeant Lloyd, his colleague, took him to the doctor. Pelham was too weak to argue. The doctor gave him medicine, and Molly took him home to rest. On Thursday, Molly told him the walnut tree in their garden fell. Pelham was too sick to care. By Saturday, he felt better and got up. He saw the living room looked different without the tree. 
Pelham's house is big with a nice garden. He liked the garden because it gave privacy. The walnut tree was nice to look at and made the room look good. Now, the room was very bright, and the old furniture looked bad. The house next door was now visible. It was tall and had many windows. Pelham did not like the view. He said to Molly, "Doesn't it look terrible?" But Molly was happy. She said, "We need a new sofa, no matter the cost."

'Living in the valley We lived in our valley for sixteen months when we first saw the dangers in the hills around us. It was the year when the storms came early, before winter, even before November ended. Before that, we felt safe in our valley with the hills around us. Soon, snow began to fall. In one day, it was 15 centimeters deep. It almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. But on the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. Up there, the wind was very strong. In our valley, we only felt some strong winds; trees moved but the branches did not break. We knew we had to worry. The snow and wind were a problem, but not too bad. It was the river, the Ryburn, that was the biggest problem. It usually flowed gently, but it could be dangerous. Many years ago, people built dams to control the water from the hills. Soon, the snow started to melt. Every day, we saw big, dark clouds over the hills. They warned us of what was coming. We watched the river, which was getting fuller and wilder. The snow melted as more rain came from the clouds. The reservoir in the hills was filling up and was almost too full. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. Water rushed over the dam and into the stream below. The river was wild near our home, just a few meters from our cottage. It was deeper than we had ever seen it, hitting its banks hard. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its wall. Luckily, it did, and the water went down. Before the dam was built, the river often flooded the villages nearby. Now, the dam controls the river, and usually, everything is okay. The water from the hills stays behind the dam, with only a little overflow sometimes. We can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and feel excited by the river's power. Thanks to the dam, we feel safe in our home in the valley.'

'Mark Adams is a film critic. He writes about movies for a newspaper called The Front Page. This was his first real job. Before this, he wrote about books and movies for other places. He met Tom Seaton, who worked at The Front Page. Tom gave him the job. Tom wanted a team to write about books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They had lunch meetings to choose what to write about. Mark felt lucky to be part of a new newspaper. He was surprised when he saw someone reading his review on the train. The team idea did not work, so they talked on the phone instead. People liked critics to write about one thing, so Mark chose films. He writes one long article each week about a film. He likes this way of working. He does not want to write about every film. He thinks people choose movies because of the stars, the ads, or the director. He does not think his reviews change people's minds much. He just wants to share his thoughts about movies. He is not a judge and does not want to be one.'

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun." Melanie is a 17-year-old girl who loves sports. She wants a training partner for triathlons. A triathlon is a sport where you swim, cycle, and run without stopping. Melanie started doing triathlons when she was 14. She won her first race because she was the only junior. In another race, she got lost and cycled too far, but she did not give up. Melanie works very hard. She was the top junior in the European Triathlon Championships. She wants to get better at cycling. Her parents help her with the cost of her sport. Melanie trains a lot, so she does not have much time for friends. She talks to her team about their race times. Melanie wants to try even harder races. She needs someone her age to train with.

'The Collectors Amanda Roy talks about collecting things and why many people like this hobby. I love collecting. One in three adults likes this hobby too. It is fun and exciting. But remember, only collect things you love. People have collected things for a long time. Long ago, people collected pretty stones. They wore them as necklaces. Today, children still collect stones and seashells because they are pretty. I have collected things all my life. I collect flowers, pottery, and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a faraway place in England. It was cold and windy. My parents took me to a museum there. It had many old things collected by people. I loved looking at them. Many people like collecting. Some people collect because it makes them feel in control. I collect because I enjoy it. A famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a 'room of wonders' with many interesting things. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. You do not need to be rich to collect. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups. I once got a special tulip from another collector. But later, someone took it from me. I also collected 350 American rag dolls. I found them all over the USA. But my collection was lost in a house fire. I was very sad. Collections can change owners. A silver spoon from a king or poet is special. Small things can become popular and cost more money. Toys from the 1950s are now worth a lot, if you kept the boxes. I did not keep mine.'

**My Job**
Four people talk about their jobs.
**Lisa - Exhibition Organiser at Science Museum**
I make exhibitions at the museum. I plan and design them. I also tell people about the exhibitions. I read about the topic first. Then, I talk to important people to decide what to show. I make sure people understand the exhibition. I plan fun activities and bring in engineers to keep it safe. Before it opens, I help make brochures to tell people about it.
**Janet - Teacher for London Taxi Drivers**
I start work at 7.30 a.m. I check the money first. Then, I make new maps for students. They learn routes for the taxi-driver test. About 50 students come to school. They find the best way to go. I help when they disagree. I give them a route and say the road is closed. They must find a new way. This helps them think.
**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**
I live by the sea and work from home. I answer phone calls and make learning materials. I also teach people about the sea. Sometimes, I take them on a boat to see sea life. This helps them understand better. I love my job because I care about the sea. But, I work for a charity, so we need more money. I can't do everything I want.
**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**
My job is different every day. I make sure we have enough books. We have high standards. People write to us about maps. I talk with other publishers about new projects. I work with a great team. But, there is too much paperwork. This means less time for fun tasks like making new products.

'Our Holiday in Ireland We always went to Ireland in June. Every year, the four of us spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. An English couple, the Malseeds, own the house. They made the house bigger, but you can't really tell. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an ad when the Malseeds still advertised. 'How about this?' he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we went to a hotel our friends liked, but we didn't like the food there. The four of us, Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and I, have played cards together for a long time. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe went to school together, so we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. We think it's a funny coincidence. 'How very nice,' Mrs. Malseed said, smiling when we arrived this year. She always knows when guests are coming and waits in the big hall that smells like flowers. 'Arthur, take the luggage up,' she told the old porter. 'Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium.' These are the names of our rooms. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of numbers. In winter, when it's quiet, she does things like that, and her husband fixes things. 'Well, well, well,' Mr. Malseed said, coming in from the kitchen. 'A hundred thousand welcomes,' he said in an Irish way. He smiled with his eyes twinkling, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and we felt our holiday had started. Nothing changed at Glencorn, everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came to greet us. 'You look younger every year, all four of you,' she said, making everyone laugh. Arthur took our bags to the rooms, carrying as much as he could and coming back for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a bit but not too long because we were tired from the trip. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because in June, Glencorn Lodge is always full. From the window, we saw some people walking on the lawns and others going to the seashore. In the morning, we would do the same: walk on the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, then come back for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. We always did this because we loved the beautiful landscape since we first came here.'

'Keeping the holiday-makers happy Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She works in Val d'Isere, France. Sarah is 24 years old and from West Sussex. She cooks and cleans for people who come to ski. They stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah finished university last summer. She studied French and History of Art. Being a chalet girl is not her career. It is a fun job for a year or two. Sarah meets many people. She does not live in the chalet. She walks to work at 7 a.m. The chalet can have 18 guests each week. Sarah eats breakfast and then makes breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans or makes afternoon tea. She finishes by 11 a.m. and goes skiing. She skis until 4.30 p.m. Sarah goes back to the chalet to make dinner. Dinner is at 8 p.m. and coffee is at 10 p.m. She cleans the kitchen after dinner. Sometimes she talks with the guests. Sarah meets her friends at night. They go out but not too late on Saturday. Sunday is her busy day. She starts work early. Breakfast is at 7 a.m. for guests leaving. After they leave, Sarah cleans everything. She also shops for the week. New guests come at 4.30 p.m. Sarah helps them with skis and boots. Then she makes dinner again. Sometimes she is very tired and goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small girl with pale skin. She looked very young, like a child, but she said she was older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore overalls and big shoes. Her hair was curly, and her face was pretty. Seymour was surprised she was at the University of Pennsylvania. She was studying leather in New Jersey for her Master's degree.
Sometimes, people called or wrote to Seymour to see his factory. He helped students by answering questions or giving a short tour. Rita was very small, like the children from Marie's class. Marie's class visited the factory many years ago. Seymour showed them how he made gloves. Marie liked the laying-off table. At this table, men shaped and pressed gloves on hot brass hands. Marie called them 'pancake hands' because they looked flat.
Rita asked Seymour questions and took notes. She wanted to know about shipments and the tannery. Seymour explained that the tannery made the leather ready for them. His family worked in the tannery. He offered to help Rita visit a tannery. He said it was an old industry, with history going back thousands of years.
Seymour's father knew a lot about leather. Seymour said glovemen loved their work. He asked Rita if she had seen anything made before. She said she saw her mother make a cake. Seymour laughed. Rita was eager to learn, like his daughter Marie. Seymour decided to show Rita how gloves are made. He asked her what size gloves she wore.

'Is it a fun job? Chris Arnot talks to four people with dream jobs. Are these jobs really as great as they seem? A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from a taxi. She is going to the airport. She cannot meet us tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles. Raquel is a personal assistant to a pop star. She travels a lot. Raquel likes her job and her boss. But she does not like flying. 'On a long flight to California, I take sleeping pills to relax,' she says. Her worst flight was on Concorde. 'It felt small with tiny windows.' When not flying, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She does paperwork, organizes the diary, attends meetings, and makes travel plans. She got the job by chance. She met a pop group manager and started working behind the scenes. She also took secretarial classes. Five years later, she became a PA. B. David Brown David Brown was an accountant and a golf caddy. He liked being a caddy more. He loves golf. Caddies get a small fee and a part of the winnings. They earn between Â£25,000 and Â£35,000, but spend a lot on travel and hotels. David was 31 when he first worked for golfer Greg Norman. 'You do more than carry bags. You give advice and read the course.' Now, he is a statistical data administrator. He uses cards from caddies to make statistics for each day's play. TV commentators, golf magazines, and golfers want these results. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a newspaper. He tries food in top restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? 'If people can pay, it's their choice,' he says. 'I would rather spend Â£120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave.' Martin was a good cook. A friend offered him a food column. Martin was an advertising agency director then. It was extra money. At 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job. 'It was a 50% pay cut,' he says. 'But I could turn my passion into a job.' He still cooks at home and cycles to stay fit. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, a popular children's writer in Britain. 'Before that, I loved words and wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I was a farmer and knew about foxes killing chickens. So I wrote The Fox Busters, my first children's story.' Where do his ideas come from? 'It's not easy. I work on them,' he says. 'I write in the mornings. I am not an early riser. After lunch, I type my morning notes. I use one finger on an old typewriter, not a laptop. I get 50 to 100 letters a week. I enjoy this part of being a writer. I try to answer them all, but I have some help now.'

In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old brick building. Around it, there were big piles of soft sawdust. The sawdust was like golden mountains. One afternoon, Michael and his friends climbed to the roof of the building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and he jumped into the sawdust. He laughed and said, "I dare you all!" His friends were scared, but one by one, they jumped and laughed too.
Later, they went back up to the roof to jump again. Everyone jumped except Michael. He was scared and stayed on the roof. His friends called him a coward and left. Michael stayed on the roof for a long time. The sun was setting, and he was sweating because he was nervous. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped. He fell on the sawdust and lay there for a while. The yard was quiet because the workers had gone home.
Michael felt ashamed and walked home slowly. He was late for dinner. His stepmother was not happy and told him he should come home on time. She was a kind woman, but Michael did not listen. He was thinking about his friends laughing at him.

'Job Help Are you not happy with your job? Do you want to change but don't know how? Kitty Doherty has some advice. Many people go to a careers adviser for help. You write about yourself and take some tests. The adviser then tells you about jobs you might like and if you need more training. I tried Career Analysts, a big company that helps with job advice. The test felt like a school exam. I was with ten people, answering questions quickly. The test had things like finding mistakes in names and numbers. After the test, I talked to an adviser. He gave me a report with his ideas. I agreed with most of it. I was not good at science and technical tests. I am glad I did not become a nurse. But I was happy to hear I made a good choice with journalism. Changing your job does not mean a big change. Donna Laney, 25, lost her job in March. She went to Career Analysts. She wanted to look at her skills and interests. She found out she was good at design. But she stayed with her skills and now works in Public Relations. She is happy with the help she got. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services. She worked at a bank for six years and wanted a new challenge. The tests showed she liked sciences. She decided to study geology. She is happier now. But not everyone finds careers advice helpful. Amanda Margetts, 24, did not find it useful. She wanted new ideas but did not like the suggestions. She felt a friend could give the same advice.'

'Fun at the Dentist's? When you go to W. Lloyd Jerome's dentist office in Glasgow, you see bright paintings on the wall and a nice blue couch. Jerome says, 'Many people only go to the dentist when they have pain. They are scared.' To help with this, he makes his office a place where people are not afraid. He does not wear a white coat because it makes people think of pain. He wants people to feel relaxed and happy. Jerome uses virtual-reality headsets to help people relax. Patients watch a film about underwater animals while he checks their teeth. Then, they see a video of their own mouth. Many people like this. The office smells nice, like oranges, not like a dentist's office. Jerome says smell is important because the usual dentist smell can make people scared. Jerome is serious about his work. He uses warm water to clean teeth, not sharp tools. It feels different but not painful. Jerome learned new ways to help patients in the United States. He thinks making things easy for patients is good for everyone. A patient comes in, and Jerome gives him tea and asks what video he wants to watch. The patient seems happy. The office feels more like a nice beauty shop than a regular dentist's office.'

Chocolate is a sweet treat that people love. It started in South America. Now, it is a big business all over the world. In the UK, people buy a lot of chocolate at Easter. They spend over Â£230 million. People also eat a lot of chocolate at Christmas.
Chocolate comes from the cacao tree. This tree grows in warm places like Africa and South America. The tree has big fruits with seeds inside. These seeds are called cacao beans. When they dry, they become cocoa beans. Long ago, the Aztecs used cocoa beans as money. They also made a drink called xocoatl, which means 'bitter water'.
In the 17th century, people in Europe started to drink chocolate. They mixed it with cinnamon and sugar. Later, in 1826, a man from the Netherlands made chocolate powder. In 1847, a company in England made the first chocolate bar. Later, a Swiss company added milk to make milk chocolate.
In the early 1900s, the English company Cadbury made a chocolate bar called Dairy Milk. It became very popular. Today, people in the UK eat about four chocolate bars each week. Chocolate companies now make chocolate ice cream and drinks to keep people interested.
Cacao farmers grow the beans to make chocolate. They work very hard but sometimes do not earn much money. So, when you eat chocolate, think about the farmers who help make it.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**
Peter Cooke is 83 years old. He is very good at making art with shells. He wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers. But now, he is happy making beautiful things with shells. 
Peter shows me his work in his home. He is very excited about his art. He shows me shell ornaments on a fireplace. He says, "I like them a lot. I don't mind if people don't buy them." 
Five years ago, friends told him to show his work in an art gallery. Many people bought his art. Now, he has a new show in London. His art is expensive. Some pieces cost PS2,000. The cheapest piece is PS225. 
Peter says he does not set the prices. He thinks his work is special. The gallery owner says, "One day, you will stop making art, and people will want your pieces." 
Peter wishes he started making shell art earlier. He says he could have made even better things. But he is happy with what he makes now. His art is different from the shell things in seaside shops. 
Peter uses many small shells to make boxes and flowers. He has his own way of working. He uses cardboard, glue, and washing-up liquid. He says, "I have an idea, and it just happens." 
Peter looks for shells in many places like France, Thailand, and Mexico. He only takes shells that are empty. He does not take shells with animals inside. He says, "People walk on shells and break them. I only take shells that are already empty." 
Peter's art is very beautiful. He makes something special from the shells he finds.

'The Schoolgirl Model Kira Langer is 15 years old. She is a model. She travels to many places and is on magazine covers. But she also studies for her school exams. I went to meet Kira. The receptionist said, 'Kira will be a little late.' I thought about models. People say models are difficult and not smart. I worried Kira might not come. But Kira came in smiling. She was with her mother. Kira wore a simple black dress and trainers. She was friendly and pretty. Models under 16 must have an adult with them. Kira's mother was proud of her. Kira did not plan to be famous. Her sister sent photos of Kira to a model competition. Kira was at school when she heard she was a finalist. She won the competition. A model agency in London gave her work. Kira has two lives: school and modeling. Her friends and teachers are proud of her. Some people at school are not nice. They say she thinks too much of herself. But Kira is still the same. She is just more confident now. Kira's social life is different. The agency can call her anytime for work. She cannot always make plans with friends. But her friends understand. Kira has a bright future. She is successful before finishing school. I asked Kira what job she would like if she was not a model. She said, 'I would like to do what you're doing.'

Title: Father and Son Look for Gold
Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son. They want to find gold. They traveled from cold Canada to hot Africa. Now, they are looking for gold in Wales, a country in the UK. They think there is a lot of gold in a mountain in Wales. They have been digging for ten years. Terence is 68 years old and from Liverpool. He says they are close to finding a lot of gold.
They started looking for gold after reading about it in old books. They found a place in Wales called the 'Dolgellau gold belt'. They got permission to dig there. They found some gold in the rocks. They have been working hard, moving rocks and cleaning the area. Now, they need more money to keep digging. They hope someone will give them money to help.
People in the town of Dolgellau are interested. They hope more tourists will come if gold is found. But they do not want too many people to come and dig everywhere.
In the past, many people worked in gold mines in Wales. But now, most mines are closed. One mine, Clogau-St David's, closed last month. It made rings for the Queen and Princess of Wales. Now, some people are starting to look for gold again. George Hall, another man, is also looking for gold. He says it is exciting to find hidden treasure. He hopes to be lucky.

'IN HOT WATER Rachel Mills is a scientist. She works at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel studies the sea. She teaches at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she goes in a small underwater car. She dives three kilometers down into the ocean. She studies underwater volcanoes. Inside the car, it is very small. She can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand up or move. They stay inside until someone opens the door. A dive takes 16 hours. It takes three hours to go down, ten hours to work, and three hours to come back up. If there is a problem, they can press a panic button. A small escape car goes up fast to the surface. No one has used it yet. Rachel has made six dives. She went with a Russian team. They went to a place near the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The Russian team put equipment there. They want to study the volcanoes. When Rachel is not at sea, she is at her office. She loves teaching, but she also loves her research. She studies "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes. Hot water comes out and looks like black smoke. It is very hot. Rachel was scared once. She was with an American team. There was a big bang. She thought she would die. But they were okay. Diving is an adventure. Rachel feels wonder when she sees the volcanoes. She studied them for three years. Seeing them for real was amazing.'

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and had a suntan. It was the end of my train holiday. My body was tired. My mind was tired of different timetables, money, and languages. "Never again," I said when I got home. But I said the same thing the next year. And the next. I just needed one train ticket. Because I was under 25 years old, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a month. Sleeping in a train corridor is different from a bed. The train rocks you to sleep. Carrying everything in a backpack makes travel simple. Sometimes, I threw away socks and books when I didn't need them. This is the Inter-Rail way. You don't need to think too much. Just have a ticket in your hand. This train ticket lets young people visit many countries quickly. On my first trip, my friends and I thought it was just a cheap way to go to a camp in France. But we wanted to travel more. There was always another country to see. And it cost us nothing extra. We liked culture, but this was our first holiday without parents. We made our own plans and saw only easy-to-reach sights. We wanted to do something different. I liked seeing the view from the train station. We were there to have fun. We shared train floors, food, water, money, and music with other travelers. Travel is exciting because you see new places. A city is just a name until you see it. You understand Europe better by seeing it yourself. Other people's holiday photos are boring because you didn't see it. The train trip is a personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps you see it. But for us, it took time to understand this.

'It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out your bags are not there. You might have to wear the same clothes for a long time until the airline finds your bags. Sometimes, you might be in a place with a different climate and your clothes are not right for it. Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens. Even good airlines make mistakes, and they cannot always make sure your bags are on the same flight as you, especially if you change planes. 
Airlines ask you to check in early so there is enough time for your bags to get on the plane. When you change planes, there is a minimum connecting time (MCT) to move bags from one plane to another. Usually, this works well. But sometimes, extra security checks and air traffic problems cause delays. This can make the baggage system fail. Sometimes, people make mistakes, or the label on your bag can fall off. These problems are worse at big airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. 
For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport had over 41 million passengers, and nine million changed planes. British Airways had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow. Even good airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The risk of losing bags is higher at some airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing bags when passengers go to Latin America.
To avoid losing your bags, choose direct flights if you can and check in early. If you must change planes, try to use the same airline and allow more time between flights. Label your bags inside and out with your home and holiday addresses and flight numbers. If your bags still go missing, talk to the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before you leave the airport.'

'The Kingfisher Charlie James is a photographer. He takes pictures of kingfishers. A kingfisher is a small, beautiful bird. It is blue and green. It lives near water and eats fish. The kingfisher flies very fast. It is hard to see because it moves quickly. Charlie loves kingfishers. He liked them when he was a child. He does not know why he loves them so much. There are old stories about kingfishers. One story says a kingfisher was a goddess who became a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew high and got its colors from the sky and sun. Kingfishers look blue, but their feathers have no blue color. The feathers reflect light, so they look blue or green. Kingfishers are shy, but you can watch them from a hiding place. Charlie used an old blanket to hide and watch kingfishers. He waited for a long time to take a good picture. He missed school to watch kingfishers. People noticed his love for the bird. At 16, he worked for a nature magazine. Now, he makes films about animals. He wants to make a film about kingfishers with no talking, just pictures. Charlie loves the colors of the kingfisher. He has spent many years with them. His pictures show his love, but there is more to his story with the kingfisher.'

'Conducting an Orchestra Conducting an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work. A. ANNE MANSON Anne Manson is 30 years old. She asked to watch conductor Claudio Abbado in Vienna. She ended up helping him. She was not nervous. Anne works with an opera company in London. She also works in other European countries. B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE Andrew Constantine is 31 years old. He won a big competition in 1991. He says it is hard to get the right opportunities. He wants people to know him for his work, not just the competition. He works with the English Chamber Orchestra. C. WASFI KANI Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera. She likes the long practice time in opera. She started conducting in her late twenties. She worked in London before Pimlico Opera became professional. She learned a lot from Sian Edwards. D. ROGER VIGNOLES Roger Vignoles is 48 years old. He started as a musician in an opera house. Last year, he conducted Handel's Agrippina. He found it easier than he thought. He wants to try new things. E. WAYNE MARSHALL Wayne Marshall was noticed by Simon Rattle in 1986. He conducted a musical in London. It was hard, but he was strong. He did not study conducting formally. He knows what he likes and is determined.'

**Theme Parks in Britain**
**Fun Island - The Burns Family**
Last year, we went to a big theme park in the US. We thought Fun Island might be boring, but it was fun! It is good for young children. Our three-year-old liked it. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special ride for very young kids, and it was a big hit. Older kids can try scary rides like Splash Out, where you jump in a pool! After five hours, we wanted to go home, but the kids wanted to stay. The park is clean and safe. The staff is very helpful.
**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**
We never went to a theme park before. We did not know what to expect. Oscar is young, but he loved it. He liked the Mountain Train and Little Land, with small famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and toy cars. We stayed for six hours. There are places to rest. The park is beautiful, and the staff is friendly. There is something for everyone, even adults.
**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**
We stayed for seven hours and still had more to see. The kids loved the Big Top Circus. We went on the Terror Line. The girls were scared but liked it. Their favorite was Running River. You think you will get wet, but you don't. Toy Land is fun for young kids. The new ride, Fear Factor, was too big for our kids. The park is clean, and the staff is nice. A staff member helped us on a ride.
**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**
We arrived at 1 p.m. and were sad the park closed at 5 p.m. This park is good for young kids. The rides are not too scary. We liked Exotic Travels, a fun boat ride. We waited 30 minutes for Lightning River, and it was over fast! I did not go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun. Older kids might find it boring, but our kids loved it.
**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**
The park says there is "No Limit to the Fun," and it is true. The Rocket is Europe's tallest roller-coaster. Ben thought it was scary. Jennie thought the Hanger was scarier. There are many rides. Older kids went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides but liked the Long Slide. Some staff were nice, but not all. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We did not want to leave early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside**
Five women talk about their businesses in the countryside.
**A. Christine Hogan**
Christine Hogan has a computer design business. She makes over Â£200,000 a year and has four workers. She moved from London to the countryside with her husband and children. She wanted to work from home. Christine used to work with computers, so her husband suggested starting a computer design business. It was hard at first and needed a lot of money. She is careful with money and tells the bank if she might spend too much. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evening. Her business is small, and local people come to pick up their work.
**B. Maggy Sasanow**
Maggy Sasanow designs greeting cards at home. She studied art and wanted to work in a museum, but there were no jobs like that in the countryside. So, she started her own business. She makes 50 different cards and sells them to museums. She works in a big room at home. She does not advertise; people hear about her from others. She is cheaper than other artists, so people send her work from London. She misses talking to other people about ideas, but she likes being independent.
**C. Delia Turner**
Delia Turner makes curtains. Her business had good and bad times. She started eight years ago. Her business grew fast, but then the economy got worse. She had to let her six workers go, which was hard because there are not many jobs in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband and other women who work from their homes. She sometimes has to lower her prices and look for new chances.
**D. Tessa Strickland**
Tessa Strickland works on children's books from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside because London was expensive and she loves the country. She likes working when she wants. Most of her money comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she takes calls at odd hours. It is hard to stop working sometimes. She works with authors and artists to publish children's books from different cultures. She used to feel alone because she worked in London before.
**E. Meg Rivers**
Meg Rivers has a cake business. She makes Â£250,000 a year and has six workers. She started at home ten years ago. She likes healthy food, so she made fruit cakes with good flour and eggs. Friends and family asked for cakes, and soon she sent cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building for her business. Now, she has a baker, an assistant, and a cake decorator. She does not bake anymore; she runs the business side. Her biggest problem was money because she did not have much to start with.

Meet the Watkins Family
The Watkins family loves music. The sons, Paul and Huw, play music and write songs. Their dad, John, makes musical instruments. 
When Paul was ten years old, he needed a cello. A cello is a big musical instrument. Buying a cello was very expensive. So, John's dad decided to make one. He went to a school to learn how to make instruments. After some practice, he made a cello for Paul. Paul used this cello for many years.
John stopped teaching and now makes violins full-time. He even sold a violin to a famous American musician, Jaime Laredo.
Paul and Huw started playing music when they were young. Paul first played the piano, then the cello. He liked the cello because he thought the cello player in his dad's music group was cool. Huw plays the piano and writes music too.
Paul won a big music competition with his dad's cello. He also played in a famous orchestra. Now, he has a new, very old cello from the Royal Academy of Music. It is 304 years old!
Paul will play this new cello on TV soon. He will play a famous piece called Elgar's Cello Concerto. But he cannot watch himself on TV because he has another concert that night. Huw also has a concert the same night in London.
John and Hetty, their parents, are very proud and busy keeping up with their sons' music events.

'Taking Care of the Countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is a group that helps keep the British countryside safe and beautiful. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, who works for the Trust. Gareth's job is to take care of the land. Gareth says you need common sense to do his job. You also need to be good with people because you talk to farmers, visitors, and builders. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his family's farm. Many people wanted Gareth's job, but he got it because he knows the area well and has farming experience. Gareth still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand farmers' problems. He is strong and can do hard work like building fences and planting trees. Gareth has learned a lot about nature. He remembers picking flowers and collecting birds' nests when he was young. Now he sees that farming has changed the countryside. Farmers and nature lovers used to disagree, but now they talk and understand each other better. Gareth's job is to make sure work gets done well and cheaply. He likes finishing projects and talking to people, even if some visitors are not nice. Gareth loves his job and being outside. If you like being outdoors and have common sense, you might want to be a warden like Gareth. But there might not be a job on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!'

'The Netball Captain
Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. She is getting ready for the World Championships next month. Every day, she teaches at a school and then practices in a supermarket car park. She is very focused on her training.
Kendra wants to be her best for the Championships. This is her fourth time at the World Championships. There will be 27 countries playing. England will have many fans watching, which is special for Kendra. The first game is against Barbados. England usually wins against them, but it will be a fun game.
England is the fourth-best team in the world. The World Championships are hard because there is only one chance to win. Kendra says you have to be ready every day.
Netball is faster and harder now. Players train a lot to win. After the game, players are friendly. Fitness is very important. Kendra wants to be a good leader for her team.
Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. She decided this will be her last competition as a player. She might coach young players in the future. At the opening ceremony, she might feel emotional because it is her last big event.'

'SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS What can you do if your child is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents do not see their child's talent until the child becomes upset. Regular schools may not have the right help for children who are very good at music. These children might do well at a special music school. In Britain, there are five special music schools. These schools help children aged seven to eighteen who are very good at music. Children at these schools spend a lot of time on music. They have lessons, play in groups, and practice singing and instruments. They also learn subjects like English and math, but not as many as in regular schools. These schools are private, and classes are small. Most children live at the school. This means they are with other children who love music too. There are some problems. The schools cost a lot of money, but they try to help with scholarships. Some parents do not want their young children to live away from home. Some people worry that starting music school too young can be stressful. Music talent can change as children grow up. The schools watch the children closely and help them if needed. Some children are also very smart and want to learn more subjects. They might be happier in a regular school with good music classes. Some music colleges offer lessons on Saturdays for children who live near big cities. This can be a good choice for families who do not live near a special music school.'

'Susan Shepherd is an artist. She paints flowers. Her house has a big garden with many flowers. She likes tulips and poppies. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. The garden looks nice because of the old owners. They loved gardening. Susan also has a gardener named Danny. She says, "It was really his garden." They work well together. Susan paints one flower at a time. She picks flowers and takes them to her studio. It can take a long time to finish a painting. Spring and early summer are busy for her because many flowers bloom. She likes to watch flowers change. Tulips change shape in water. Susan liked wild flowers when she was young. She thought garden flowers looked fake. Now, her garden has plants from far places like China. She lets the garden grow freely. Susan is busy with two art shows. She has a new gardener to help. But she still likes to work in the garden herself.'

'Working as a Chalet Girl Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and from West Sussex. Sarah works in Val d'IsÃ¨re, France. She cooks and cleans for people who come to ski. They stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah studied French and History of Art at university. She says being a chalet girl is fun for a year or two. She meets many people. Sarah does not live at the chalet. She walks there every morning. She makes breakfast for the guests. They eat porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans the rooms. She does not like this part of the job. Then she goes skiing. She skis until 4:30 p.m. Sarah goes back to the chalet to make dinner. Dinner is at 8 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. Sometimes she talks with the guests. Other times, she leaves them alone. Sarah meets her friends at night. They go out to places like Bananas and Dick's T-Bar. On Saturday night, she does not stay out late. Sunday is her busiest day. She makes breakfast early. After guests leave, she cleans the chalet. She also goes shopping if needed. New guests arrive in the afternoon. Sarah helps them with skis and boots. Then she makes dinner again. Sometimes she is very tired and goes to bed early.'

**Changing Jobs for a Day**
**Mandie Currie, Zoo-Keeper:**
Mandie works at a zoo. She spent one day at a magazine office. She usually wears a uniform, but she had to choose clothes for the office. She visited a photo studio and press events. At the zoo, she is calm and happy. The magazine office was busy. She laughed because she usually cleans cages and handles animals. Mandie likes her zoo job and wants to stay there.
**Alice Cutler, Fashion Assistant:**
Alice works at a magazine. She spent one day at the zoo. She wore leather boots and blue trousers, but the zoo gave her a green shirt. She got dirty but had fun. She touched an elephant and thought about Mandie packing clothes. Alice enjoyed the day and thinks she might work with elephants in Africa one day.
**Karen Hodson, Nurse:**
Karen is a nurse. She spent one day with a TV gardening team. She was excited to meet the team. She liked being outside because she usually works inside. The work was hard but fun. Karen thought gardening was easy, but it was not. She likes her nurse job and will not change it.
**Charlie Dimmock, Gardener:**
Charlie is a gardener on TV. He spent one day at a hospital. He made beds and gave out medicine. He thought he would feel sick, but he was okay. The nurses were friendly. Charlie felt his job was not as important as nursing. He felt good after working at the hospital.
**Lucy Harvey, Personal Trainer:**
Lucy works in a gym. She spent one day as a flight attendant. She wore a uniform and felt important. She learned about safety on the plane. She gave magazines to passengers. On the way back, there were many children on the plane. Lucy wanted to be back in the gym.
**Sonia McDermott, Air Hostess:**
Sonia works on a plane. She spent one day as a personal trainer. She was nervous because she does not exercise. She was surprised by how much attention trainers give to one person. **On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Train Stories**

I love the south of France. I go there often. There is a train from Cannes to Italy. The view is beautiful. You see the sea and nice houses. The people on the train are fun. They are tourists and locals. Everyone enjoys the trip.

I like many train trips. My favorite is the Nile Valley Express in Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a train trip to Kruger National Park. I was too young. My first train station was London Waterloo. It was amazing.

I love the Blue Train. My husband and I took it on our honeymoon in France. He gave me a pink dress on the train. I love pink now. The trip was nice. We went to Egypt by boat. It was a great way to relax after our wedding.

We were on a world trip and needed to cross a desert in Africa. We took the Desert Express train. The train did not have a set time. Many people got on the train, even on the roof. At night, the view was beautiful. It felt like a dream.
