I did not see many trains as a child in Singapore and Cyprus. As a teenager, I made a film in Yorkshire with a train. I loved steam trains. We rode the train when not filming. I went back last year, and it looked the same.

'Do you want to publish your story? Our expert, Margaret Stubbs, can help you. Many people ask, 'I wrote a story. Who should I send it to?' First, you need to learn about publishers and practice writing. To sell your story, you need to know about the 'writing world'. Read a lot to know what publishers like. Visit your library and bookshops. New magazines and books come out all the time, so keep learning. Publishers want new writers. If you want to write love stories, find magazines that like them. Read these magazines to know what stories they want. Writers often ask, 'My story was rejected. Should I keep trying?' I say yes, but maybe the story needs more work. Many new writers send their stories too soon. If you wrote only one story, it might not get published. Successful writers often work for years before they succeed. When you send your story, start writing more. Write ten or twenty more stories. Each story will be better. Don't throw them away; make them better. Don't show your work to others too soon. Remember, many writers get rejected before they succeed. Try to join a writing class or group. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

On the last day of a bad year, I was at the Baltimore train station. I was waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were many people there. The station did not feel nice and clean like usual. 
Old couples with matching bags sat on the benches. Many college students sat on the floor with their bags. A man with grey hair was talking to people. He looked rich. He wore a nice sweater and a soft coat. 
He asked a woman if she was going to Philadelphia. Then he asked a girl near me. She had long blond hair. I thought I might talk to her too. The man asked, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said, "No, I am going to New York." The man said, "Thanks," and moved on.
He asked an old lady, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said, "Wilmington." He did not say anything and walked to another couple. I was going to Philadelphia, but he did not ask me. Maybe he thought I looked unreliable.
The man looked worried. He asked a woman reading a book, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said, "Yes, I am." He asked her for a favor. I pretended to look at my watch, but I don't have one.
The man said his daughter was flying out for a study year abroad. She forgot her passport. She called from Philadelphia. He told her to wait there. He wanted someone to take her passport to her.
The woman asked, "Why don't you go yourself?" He said, "I can't leave my wife alone. She is in a wheelchair." I thought this was a bad excuse. 
The man held a padded envelope. It was big and stapled shut. I thought, "Be careful, lady."

Title: Gary and Me
John Moore owns a restaurant. He talks about his son, Gary, who is a famous TV chef.
John believes everyone gets a chance in life. Gary's chance was cooking, and John's chance was running a restaurant. When John found the restaurant, it was not in good shape, but he liked it. It reminded him of his childhood. His mother worked in a factory, and he was sad to be alone. So, he wanted to have time for family.
John's wife took care of their children and helped with the business. They lived above the restaurant and always ate meals together. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. The children talked to customers, which was good for them.
Gary was a lively child. Once, he jumped into a bath like a pool and got hurt. As he grew, he worked for pocket money. He did small jobs and helped in the kitchen. By age 10, he had a lot of money at school. He was disciplined and woke up early to help.
Gary was not great at school, but he was very good in the kitchen. By age 15, he was as good as the adults and sometimes in charge. He made many meals and was very talented. John knew Gary would work in catering.
When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend's restaurant. Gary also plays drums and has a band. John advises Gary to focus on one thing to succeed.
Gary went to catering college at 17. On his first day, he finished his work quickly and helped others. John is proud of Gary's success on TV. He taught Gary to work hard for what he wants. Gary listened and learned from his father.

'Finding a Flat in Dublin Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can pay for is very hard. The best way is to know someone who knows someone leaving a flat. But if you are new, like Jo, you don't know anyone. Jo had to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. Dublin was a big unknown place for her. She didn't think much about why she was going there. Everyone from her school wanted to leave their small town and see more of the world. Some went to towns like Ennis or Limerick. But Jo was the only one going to Dublin. Jo's mom thought it was good for her to stay in the hostel. It was safe because nuns ran it. Her dad hoped it was warm because hostels can be cold. Her sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a week. Jo didn't know they were talking about her. She saw an ad for a flat in Ringsend. It said, 'Own room, own TV, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was close to her work at the post office. She hoped it was nice and not too expensive. There was no line for this flat because it was more like 'Third Girl Wanted.' The 'own TV' part made Jo think it might be too fancy, but the house looked normal. It was a red-brick house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A girl with a college scarf was leaving and said, 'Desperate place. They're both awful.' Jo kept going up. 'Hello,' said a girl with 'Nessa' on her T-shirt. 'Did you see that girl leaving? I don't like her type.' 'What did she do?' asked Jo. 'She just looked around, made a face, and said, "Is this all?" in a fancy voice. We wouldn't have her here, right, Pauline?' Pauline wore a very colorful shirt and had bright hair. Jo was surprised because Pauline was a punk. Jo had seen punks before but never talked to one. 'I'm Jo, I work at the post office,' she said. Nessa said they were about to have tea. She had three mugs: one for Nessa, one for Pauline, and one that said 'Other.' 'We'll put your name on it if you stay,' Nessa said.'

'Dolphins and Their Problems People like dolphins. We like to see them at the beach, in movies, and on TV. But dolphins have big problems. Mark Simmonds talks about why dolphins are in danger. Dolphins are smart animals. They understand people and make us think of freedom in the sea. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest make us love dolphins more. But real life is hard for dolphins. The sea is dirty and there are not many fish. One type of dolphin, the North Sea harbour porpoise, has fewer numbers now. We think there are 89,000 less than before. Many people think dolphins are safe and protected. But this is not true. There are 40 kinds of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, we see striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and harbour porpoises. Striped and common dolphins live far in the sea. We do not know much about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be near the coast. Now, they are only in a few places in Scotland and Wales. They have skin problems because they are stressed. It is hard to know why there are fewer dolphins. There are not many fish because of too much fishing. Dolphins need fish to eat. If there are no fish, dolphins cannot find food. Dolphins can also get caught in fishing nets. These nets are hard for dolphins to see. Many dead dolphins are found on beaches in France and Cornwall. They have marks from nets. The sea is also dirty. Dolphins can eat bad things in the water. These bad things stay in their bodies. Mother dolphins can give bad milk to their babies. One baby dolphin died from its mother's milk. Noise in the sea is another problem. Dolphins use sound to understand their world. Noise from ships and oil wells can confuse them. We do not know how much this hurts dolphins.'

**GETTING FIT**
Exercise is very important for your body and mind. It helps you feel good when life is busy and stressful. Exercise is good for you, and there are many reasons to do it.
Exercise makes your muscles strong and changes your body shape. It helps you stand or sit well. It also helps your heart and lungs work better. Exercise can make you feel less sad and tired. It helps you sleep better and feel less stressed.
There are many types of exercise you can try, like jogging, lifting weights, or using machines. But be careful not to exercise too hard, or you might get hurt. Start slowly and ask a doctor if you are unsure.
Good posture is important. Stand up straight to look and feel better. Imagine a balloon pulling your head up to help you stand tall. Stretching your muscles helps you move easily and prevents injuries. Stretching should be part of your exercise routine.
A good exercise routine includes warming up, stretching, working out, and cooling down. Do this four or five times a week for a healthy body.

'IN THEIR NATURAL HOME What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their comfortable homes for many months? They want to find the perfect picture. Amanda and Owen work in East Africa, in places like the Ngorongoro Crater. It rains a lot there, which makes their work hard. They bought a special tool to help when their car gets stuck in the mud. Amanda and Owen make great wildlife films for TV. They made a famous film about leopards. Now, they are making a film about jackals. Amanda and Owen travel a lot to film animals. They sometimes argue, but they become friends again quickly. They both love animals and see them in the same way. They sleep in tents and wake up early. They make tea the night before and keep it warm. They eat simple meals from packets. They stay in the wild for up to eight weeks. They like being close to animals. Once, a lioness treated their car like part of her family. Amanda and Owen started working together in 1988. They need four months to make a 30-minute film. They write a plan before they start filming. Amanda and Owen work well together because they have the same ideas. They want to make films that show the true spirit of the place and animals. They want people to feel something when they watch their films.'

Rachel Mills is a scientist. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. Rachel studies the sea and teaches students. She likes to go to the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She uses a small underwater vehicle to go down. It is the size of a small car. Inside, there is not much space. She can touch the two pilots next to her. They stay inside for 16 hours. It takes three hours to go down, ten hours to work, and three hours to come back up.
If there is a problem, they can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vehicle go up fast. It is like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has used it yet.
Rachel has made six dives. She went with a Russian team to study underwater volcanoes. These volcanoes blow out black smoke. This is called "black smokers." The water comes out very hot, at 350 degrees.
Rachel loves her work. She feels excited when she sees the volcanoes. She studied them for three years. Seeing them in real life is amazing for her.

**Interview Tips**
When you meet someone for the first time, they quickly decide what they think about you. They look at your clothes, eyes, body, and how you talk. Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She worked hard and finished school. She went to a job interview at a school. She saw a small hole in her jacket but did not change because she wanted to be on time. Mary did not get the job. The Head Teacher thought she did not care about her appearance.
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says people who look after themselves will look after their jobs. In an interview, you should look your best. Some people forget this. Janet Goodwood worked in an office for ten years. She wanted a better job but did not get an interview. The boss said she did not look like a manager. He told her to dress better next time.
How you move and your face also matter in an interview. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian says only 7% of what we say is from words. The rest is from our voice and face. Make sure your face and words match. Do not look too eager or desperate for the job.
Sheila Rice, a marketing expert, got a job offer in an interview. She was very happy, but the boss saw this and gave her less money. She thinks she could have got more if she was calmer.
Before an interview, learn about the company. David Artesio, a job agency manager, says to talk about something you like about the company. This shows you are interested. Marian Woodall, a business consultant, says to ask questions and speak clearly. Use short sentences.

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt was an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years. It was not fun anymore. He lost his job suddenly. He used the money he got to start the farm. He met a chef from a big hotel. The chef liked his meat. Now, Matt sells meat to many people. He is happy not to be in an office. He still works a lot, but he likes it.

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby. He liked it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. He talked to a career counselor. The counselor was surprised because Ron did not want to go back to his old job. Ron and his family moved to the north of England. They did not know anyone there. They left their friends, but their friends visit them now.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. Now, she makes hats. She liked her job, but the hours were long. She did not want to work more, so she left. People said she would get bored, but she did not. Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur. He liked the excitement of finance but not the work. He almost lost his job in 1989. He left and traveled for a year. **Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**
**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I love sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and running. When I was 14, I tried to join a football club, but I chose running instead. My best moment was when I ran for my country and won a medal. I hoped for more attention and money for training, but it didn't happen. I train at home in winter and go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun there, but I must be serious. If friends ask me to go out before training, I say no. In surfing, you meet the same people at competitions. Surfers are serious, and the best waves are early in the morning. So, I don't go to late-night parties. I like to sleep in, but I can't. On the boat with my team, we have fun. We celebrate wins in a big way. Some people say we act like kids, but we don't look for media attention. It's great to play tennis and have the crowd cheer for you. But sometimes, it gets too busy with fans. I like when fans notice me, but my last girlfriend didn't like it. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up. It's hard, but you must be serious in sports. I focus on my game now and will enjoy other things after I stop playing tennis.

'Shopping with Kids Shopping with children can be very hard. One mother says, "They want everything they see. They want sweet cereal, Disney videos, or comics. I can't buy all these things. I feel bad if I say yes, and I feel bad if I say no. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to choose things." Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. A lot of money is spent on ads for children, mostly on TV. These ads make children want to buy things. Parents find it hard to explain why they can't buy everything. Ads make things look very nice. Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Parents care about what their children eat. They have ideas about healthy food, but they are not always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view." TV ads can't tell children to ask their parents to buy things, but they still make children want to buy. Parents feel stressed when deciding what to buy for their children. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food. Her son is now critical of ads. They have fewer problems in the supermarket because the children don't ask for things she won't buy. Parents also say they are not always fair. Mike, a father, says, "We say no to sweets for our son because they are bad for him, but we buy chocolate for ourselves. It's nice to buy good things, and children want that too. But I still get annoyed when they ask for things. It depends on how I feel. If I'm happy, I might say yes. It's hard to always be fair." Supermarkets can help by not putting sweets near the checkout or by having play areas for children. Parents might buy less, but they would enjoy shopping more without their children's demands.'

'The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It is made from four old houses. The hotel has new technology for staff and guests. The manager, Peter MacCann, wants staff to know guests' names. The hotel computer remembers what guests like. For example, if a guest likes certain music, it will be ready for them next time. The hotel spent a lot of money on this system, but it will help in the future. Guests can change the room temperature a little, or ask the front desk to change it more. Business guests will like the technology in the rooms. Each room has phones, a fax machine, and video-conferencing. The hotel is ready for new technology changes. TVs and DVD players can be updated. The rooms are big and comfortable. The hotel has a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, restaurants, and a garden. The food is very good. Chef Patrick Guilbaud has a restaurant in the hotel. He has two Michelin stars. The hotel and the restaurant work well together. The Merrion Hotel has good technology and staff, so it will do well.'

**Where I Get My Energy**
Emma Marsden asked six women how they stay energetic. Here is what they said:
**A. Jeanette Kupfermann - Journalist and Author:**  
"I get energy from excitement. I like doing new and challenging things. Learning gives me energy. I am learning flamenco dancing now. Dance is fun and gives me energy. If you are bored, you feel tired. Doing something useful, even if it's small, gives you energy."
**B. Linda Kelsey - Magazine Editor:**  
"I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. If you like what you do, you don't feel tired. I need a lot of sleep to feel good. Exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to start. I do yoga once a week and try to exercise at home. Exercise makes me feel happy. I feel tired in the afternoon, so I eat something then."
**C. Annie Nightingale - Disc Jockey:**  
"I get energy from being happy and positive. I don't like negative people. I think we should enjoy life. I love my job and being around young people. I like taking photos and writing songs for fun. It helps me relax when I travel."
**D. Floella Benjamin - Author and Children's TV Presenter:**  
"My energy comes from doing things I love. I believe in my work and family. Being positive helps. I love working with kids because they are full of energy. Smiling at people makes me feel good. I try to eat healthy and don't smoke or drink. I play with kids for exercise."
**E. Deborah Moggach - Author and Playwright:**  
"I love making gardens. I once turned a concrete place into a garden. It was better than exercise. I get energy when people read my writing. I like exploring nature, even if it's private land. It makes me feel like a child."
**F. Katherine Monblot - Therapist:**  
"You need to like and respect what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me active. Doing things you don't like makes you tired. I used to be on committees, but they took too much of my time. Use your energy for important things."

**ICE SKATING**
Ice skating is very old. People have skated for thousands of years. Long ago, people used skates made from animal bones. Later, they used iron skates. In Scandinavia, rich people thought skating was important. 
In 1924, a girl named Sonja Henie changed skating. She made it more fun and active. Today, skating is both beautiful and hard work. 
When you start skating, balance is important. You need to control your body. Your legs should be a little bent, and your knees should be soft. This helps you stay balanced. Relaxing is very important in skating. 
To start skating, your heels should be close, and your feet should point out. Push with one foot and move the other foot a little. It is not too hard. As you get better, you can move more. 
Falling is part of skating. Everyone falls, even the best skaters. To fall safely, stay relaxed. To get up, use your hands and knees, then stand. 
Once you can skate well, you can try different styles like figure skating or speed skating. It is good to learn figure skating first. Many ice rinks have teachers to help you. 
Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To be like them, do exercises. Warm up your legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees before skating. After skating, do the exercises again to stay loose. 
Skating helps your balance and makes you strong. It is good for your heart and lungs. Skating with swimming or jogging is great for your health.

**Trills and Medals**
**A. Annika Reeder, 15 years old**
Annika won a gold medal in gymnastics. She wants to be a physiotherapist and go to the Olympics. She works very hard. She does not have time to watch TV or go out with friends. She trains every day. Sometimes, when she is very tired, her coach gives her a day off.
**Annika's Mother**
Annika was very good at gymnastics from a young age. Some parents push their children too much, but Annika loves gymnastics. It has made her more confident. Before, she was shy and hid behind her mom. Now, she has friends from all over the world.
**B. Sarah Stokes**
Sarah started show-jumping at 10 years old. She won the British National Championship. Her parents help her train and take her to shows. She loves show-jumping and wants to win a gold medal at the Olympics.
**Sarah's Mother**
Sarah loved horses from age 1. At 5, she got up early to ride her pony. They travel all over England for shows. Sarah is very happy on a horse. Watching her succeed is wonderful.
**C. Jane McShane, 10 years old**
Jane is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. She likes chess tournaments because they are fun and friendly. She does not talk about her success at school because she does not like to feel embarrassed.
**Jane's Mother**
Jane played chess for the first time at 5 years old. She loved it and learned quickly. By 6, she was beating adults. Her mother is happy when Jane wins, but she will support Jane if she wants to stop playing. Jane has a special talent, and her mother wants her to use it.

'We are all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, 'Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already very tall. Now, Chris is 228 cm tall and is the tallest man in Britain. People in Europe are getting taller by about one centimeter every ten years. More tall people are being born each year. This does not mean we are becoming a new super race. We are becoming like people from 40,000 years ago. Long ago, people ate many different plants and animals. About 9,000 years ago, farming started. Farmers grew wheat, rice, and corn. These foods are not very healthy. People became less healthy and shorter. In the US, Europe, and Japan, people are eating better now. So, people are getting taller again. In the US, the average man is 179 cm tall. In Holland, it is 180 cm, and in Japan, it is 177 cm. But there are problems. Beds are still the same size as in 1860. There is less space in planes and trains. Clothes makers have to make bigger clothes. We cannot grow taller forever. Scientists think we might stop growing at 193 cm. But, as the Earth gets warmer, people might get smaller again.

'Studio Audiences What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a normal part of TV, but many people don't know much about them. We see them on game shows and wonder - who are these people? Some people think studio audiences are not very important. Even people who work in TV sometimes don't respect them. I thought studio audiences were just people who wanted to be on TV for a short time. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from all kinds of jobs and backgrounds. TV shows try to get different people for different shows. Some people like to watch TV at home and don't understand why others go to a studio. Why get tickets, travel far, and wait for hours in a studio to watch something you can see at home? Some think people want to be on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I talked to Angela. She came because she wanted to be on TV. Others are curious to see behind the scenes. But many people go because a friend gave them a ticket. Not many of us have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. You sit with strangers, and someone shows signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh. This is true for some shows, but not all. One studio manager says, 'We hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.' Is there a difference between watching in a studio and at home? Claire thinks sitting in a studio is 'more exciting'. Charlotte liked being part of live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. At home, you miss a lot.' I missed seeing live actors because I could only see the back of someone's head. The first scenes were so far away that I watched on a studio screen. Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most people, it was just fun and a free night out.'

**Bruce**  
I like places with people. I don't like empty places. I like villages with old buildings. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I rode my bike to a village called Lastingham. I liked to ride my bike and see the hills and valleys. I am from Scotland, so the place felt like home. I wrote about my trips in a diary. This was my first try at writing about travel.
**Sophia**  
There is a small train from Hythe to Dungeness. I like to ride first class because it is not much more money. The view is simple. The train goes past fields with sheep and a canal. I like when the train goes through gardens. I see people making tea or washing dishes. I like the simple view of fields, sheep, and the sea.
**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to get to and have rocks. Not many people come here. Some surfers come, but most people like to look at the sea. The coast is known for shipwrecks. There are walks by the sea and in valleys with trees and flowers. We stay in a small house with a family in a village called Southole.
**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It is good for walking. Not many people live or visit there. I found it when I was a student. I go there every year, sometimes with my family. It has not changed much. I like going there with my son. I feel sad he grows up in a city.
**James**  
I bought my favorite house in Britain, called Glenthorne. I wanted peace and to feel at home. I grew up in Sri Lanka but went to school in Devon, England. I rode my bike around the moors and villages. We had a story about a place we never went past. That place was Glenthorne. It is a quiet and special house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

Title: ANIMAL ADVENTURE
We love animals and have many at home. One day, my daughter called me at work. She found a snake and asked, "Can we keep it?" I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We have a special tank for animals we find.
When I got home, I heard my children shouting, "Help, Mom!" I ran to their room. Our cat, Domino, had caught Bianca, a white mouse. Domino ran around the room with the mouse in his mouth. I tried to catch Domino but tripped and fell.
Then, I saw the snake escaping from its tank. The room was crazy with the cat, mouse, kids, and snake. The dog was barking too. I turned off the boiling pot in the kitchen and came back. I caught Domino and saved the mouse. The mouse was okay.
Next, I had to catch the snake. I sat on the floor and waited. Slowly, the snake calmed down. I picked it up and took it to the garden. I wanted it to go to a tree, but the snake wrapped around my shoulders. My oldest child, DJ, said, "Mom, you're warm, and the shed isn't."
We all helped the snake move to the tree. It climbed up and disappeared over the roof. My little child, Clay, said, "Wow, that was a big snake!"

'Write me a letter! Today, we use phones, fax machines, and computers a lot. But writing letters is not as common anymore. I think getting a letter is special. It is exciting to see who sent it and to read what they wrote. I have been writing letters for a long time. I started with small notes to my mother. She always told me to write thank-you letters for gifts. It did not matter if they were short or messy. When I was 18, I moved to London to study medicine. I wrote letters to my mother every week, and she wrote back. Sometimes my father wrote too. His letters were funny and made me happy. The letters talked about everyday things. We also called each other, but I remember the letters more. I also got letters from boyfriends. Writing letters helped our relationships. I could say things in writing that were hard to say out loud. I like letters with birthday or Christmas cards. It is nice to get news from the whole year. I also like letters from other countries. I have friends in Sri Lanka, Australia, and Canada. I also have a friend in France. We met in a restaurant and started writing to each other. She does not speak English, so I practice my French. We have visited each otherâ€™s homes. My biggest letter-writing success was meeting my American penfriend in Texas. We wrote letters for 29 years before we met. People were surprised our friendship lasted so long. My children also write letters. I tell them to write thank-you letters too. My daughter writes me little notes. She and my son have penfriends in Texas. I think writing letters is important and should not be forgotten.'

Title: Tourists Damage Old Rock Art in France
In France, there are very old pictures on rocks in the mountains. These pictures are 4,000 years old. They show cows, fields, and gods. Many people visit this place, but some tourists are not careful. They write on the rocks and damage the pictures. 
Jean Clottes, a rock art expert, says the pictures might be gone in 50 years if this continues. Some tourists even take pieces of the rock home. Others rub the pictures to see them better, which also causes damage.
Experts have different ideas on how to protect the pictures. Henry de Lumley thinks the mountain should be closed to visitors, except for guided tours. But Jean Clottes and David Lavergne do not agree. They want people to visit but worry about money for guards to protect the site.
Annie Echassoux, another expert, is worried because more tourists can now reach the site easily. She thinks the area should be closed off with ropes and have guides. She says money must be found to protect the pictures for future generations.

'Shopping with Kids Shopping with children can be very hard. One mother says, "They want everything they see. They want sweet cereal, a Disney video, or a comic. I can't buy all these things. I feel bad if I say yes, and I feel bad if I say no. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to choose things." Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. A lot of money is spent on ads for children, mostly on TV. These ads make children want to buy things. Parents find it hard to say no because ads are very convincing. Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Parents care about what their children eat. They want to give them healthy food. But children see ads on TV and get a one-sided view." TV ads cannot tell children to ask their parents to buy things, but they still make children want to buy them. Some parents feel stressed when shopping with children because they have to decide what to buy and what not to buy. One mother says she talks to her children about food and ads. Her son listens to ads but is critical of them. They talk about products and look at labels. Now, her children don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents also say they are not always fair. Mike, a father, says, "We say no to sweets for our son because they are bad for him, but we buy chocolate for ourselves. It's nice to buy good things, and children want that too. But I still get annoyed when they ask for things. It depends on how I feel. If I'm happy, I might say yes. It's hard to always be fair." Supermarkets can help by not putting sweets near the checkout or by having play areas for children. Parents might spend less, but shopping without children asking for things could bring more customers.'

'Climbing Walls Long ago, climbers went to mountains. Now, people can climb anywhere, inside or outside. At the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham, a French climber named Francois Lombard is climbing on a wall. The National Indoor Arena, where the event is held, is also known for the TV show Gladiators. Both have a big wall. In the past, climbers practiced on cliffs. In winter, they walked or climbed in Scotland. To stay fit, they used brick or stone buildings to practice. Later, sports centers built special climbing walls. Don Robinson, a teacher, made a climbing wall at Leeds University in the 1960s. He used natural rock in concrete. Many walls like this were built in the 1970s. But these walls had problems. They were only straight up and down. Real cliffs have different shapes. In 1985, Francois Savigny from France made new shapes for walls. These could be changed when climbers got bored. French companies also made panels with steel frames. These were lighter and could be moved. Climbers could have new challenges all the time.'

'Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they might say it is "risky." Acting is a risky job because there are many actors, but not many jobs. Some friends might say you are crazy, but others might not. Everyone will give different advice. It is your choice, and you must be responsible for it. There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no exams to pass, and no guarantee you will get a job after training. You need luck and talent. People want new actors, and acting can be exciting and glamorous. Sometimes, it can also be rewarding. Talent is a natural skill and imagination. It is also about courage and belief in what you do. Why do people want to act? It is hard to say. In the theater, the important thing is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is why actors love to act. If you ask actors how they succeed, they might not know. They know about their skills and others' skills, but they do not take success for granted. They know they are only as good as their current job. Disappointment is hard for actors. Last month, you might have been out of work. Then, you get an audition, but you might not get the job. Actors do not talk about their chances. They find ways to handle stress and rejection. Nobody likes rejection. From the start, you must be ready for it. You say you are available, willing, and talented. It is up to you to care, because if you do not care, no one else will.'

The teacher joked, 'Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already very tall. Now, Chris is 228 cm tall and is the tallest man in Britain. People in Europe are getting taller by about one centimeter every ten years. More tall people are being born each year. This does not mean we are becoming a new super race. **A New Life**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt was an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years. It was not fun anymore. He lost his job suddenly. He used the money to start the farm. He met a chef from a big hotel. The chef liked his meat. Now, Matt sells meat by mail too. He works a lot but is happy not to be in an office.
**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby. He liked it more than his job. He chose to leave his job. A career counselor helped him. Ron and his family moved to the north of England. They did not know anyone there. They left their friends, but friends visit them now.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. Now, she makes hats. Her job was fun and paid well, but the hours were long. She did not want to work more hours. People said she would get bored, but she did not. She likes having deadlines. She is happier and less stressed now. She misses talking to colleagues. She likes being responsible for her work.
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur in London. He liked the excitement of finance but not the work. He almost lost his job in 1989. He quit and traveled for a year. He wanted to work in health. He learned massage and got a job. He is happy now and feels in control of his life.

**Two Brothers and Their Game**
Dave and Norm Lagasse are brothers. They live in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA. They like to play a game called pichenotte. Their grandfather, Lucien, brought the game from Quebec, Canada. The family played it a lot on weekends and holidays.
Pichenotte is a game with a wooden board and round pieces. You flick the pieces with your finger. The goal is to get the pieces into a small hole. The game is fun and lasts about two minutes.
One day, Dave made a new pichenotte board. People liked it and wanted to buy it. The brothers took the board to a bar. People there loved the game too. They started selling the boards at markets and fairs. The game became very popular.
Now, Dave and Norm make pichenotte boards full-time. They have a workshop in their garage. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany. They sell the boards for $595 on their website.
The brothers hope the game will make them rich. They dream of buying a luxury car one day. For now, they are happy playing and selling pichenotte.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**
Hello! Welcome to the Model Village. A few years ago, this place was just empty land with lots of bushes. It was not useful. But one man and his wife worked very hard to make it beautiful. They moved a lot of soil to make hills and gardens. They used machines and also worked with their hands. They brought in good soil to grow grass, flowers, and trees.
They planted many trees and bushes. These plants can live near the sea and in strong winds. Some plants came from nearby, and some came from far places like Canada and New Zealand.
Colin Sims made the village. He started in 1972 and worked for nine years. He made over 100 models. The models are made from stone, wood, and plastic. They can stay strong in any weather. Colin learned from experts and became very good at making models.
The models are all the same size and have lots of details. The village is very popular because it looks real and is well-made. Other places in England use the same way to make model villages.
The buildings look like old British houses. One big building is the Manor House. It looks like a house from the 13th century. You can also see a castle, a church, a zoo, and a mini golf course.
Please stay on the paths and do not touch the models. You can take photos from the paths. Dogs can come if they are on a short lead. Some models have buttons. Press them to see the models move.
At the end of your visit, please tell us what you think. We are always making new models and want to know your ideas. We also want to know if any models need fixing. We hope you have a good time and come back again. Tell your friends about us!

'Every week, British newspapers show pictures that invade people's privacy. Sometimes, pop stars let photographers take their pictures, but this is not common. Often, these pictures hurt famous people because they show private moments. There is a group called the Press Complaints Commission (PCC) that can help with this problem, but not many people ask for their help. These pictures do not help the public. For example, a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony does not help anyone. The actress was upset about these pictures, but she did not complain. The PCC did not do anything about it, which is surprising. They should also look at stories about pop stars' private lives. The pop star did not complain either. Shouldn't the PCC do something about these problems? 
If the PCC acted like a 'police officer', it would be hard. How would they decide to start an investigation? Should they ask the person to complain? And if the person does not want to, should they still do it? Also, famous people might think every story about them should be checked, and they might be upset if it is not. The job is too big. How can the PCC watch all newspapers and magazines in Britain? 
There is also the problem of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, do they want more attention from an investigation? Most people just want to forget and move on. Some might have other reasons to stay quiet. They might have a worse story they want to keep secret. 
One British comedian had his privacy invaded when he was on his honeymoon. He did not complain because he was afraid the newspaper would make fun of him. People are scared to fight the newspapers because they think they will be targeted again. This is a difficult problem to solve.'

'There is a lot of advice for students who finish college and start their first job. This article talks about moving to a second job. We are not talking about people looking for a short job while finding a permanent one. We are also not talking about people leaving a bad job in the first few weeks. We are talking about people who want to move up in their career. You have learned some skills and know what you want. What kind of job should you look for? It depends on what you want in the future. Do you want to be an expert in one area? Do you want more responsibility? Do you want to try a different field? Choose your second job carefully. You should stay in it for two to three years. This job is important for your next job application. It should show you are serious about your career. It should help you grow and give you more responsibility. If you want to travel, now is a good time. You can do temporary work when you come back and then find your second job. Future employers will be happy to see you have traveled and are ready to work. Juliette Davidson worked for three lawyers after college. It was a good first job. She learned office work and improved her computer skills. But there was no chance to move up. She left, traveled for a year, and now works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, a Chief Executive. In two and a half years, Juliette's job has grown. She started with typing and phone work. Now she does most of the letters and budgets. She also answers questions from company leaders and people starting businesses. Brenda gives her projects and events to organize.'

Title: How to Be Confident
Confident people look strong, but they learn to be this way. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.
A. Jenny
When I left school, I was very shy. At 25, I helped at my daughter's school. I was scared but did well. Someone said I should go to university. I was nervous at first, but my confidence grew. Working at the school changed my life.
B. Michaela
Four years ago, my dad got sick, and I took over the family business. I was scared and acted too strong. I learned that to be confident, you must believe in yourself. If work is hard, I save some tasks for the next day. I tell myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you less confident, so I talk to myself to feel better.
C. Lisa
People think I am confident, but I get scared. In TV, I must look confident. Interviewing people showed me that everyone gets nervous. My mom said, "Who's looking at you? Everyone worries about themselves." This helps me. I also gain confidence by doing things that scare me. I was nervous for my driving test, but I passed. Now, I am less scared.
D. Barbara
I love my work, and this gives me confidence. I learn from mistakes and become more confident. I work hard and am liked, but not everyone likes me. I like myself for who I am. My company has training courses that help me. Setting small goals helps me see my progress.
E. Kim
After college, I was a secretary. I was scared to speak in meetings. I learned to speak up. In politics, I was nervous to speak in public. I told myself, "People do this every day, so you can too." Writing notes helped me feel better. Everyone gets nervous speaking in public. Confidence is telling yourself, "Nothing is impossible."

'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster goes to a kite festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his broken kite. 'You can keep it,' he said, 'if the line breaks, you can keep the kite. I have many more.' He showed me a pile of kites. They were all 120cm wide and long, made of paper and bamboo. We sat under the trees near the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, Malaysia. We watched the big kite festival. In the middle of the beach, there were 10 platforms. Helpers held the kites, and people waited to fly them. When the whistle blew, the kites went up like rockets. More than 500 men and boys joined the competition. It lasts five days every year. They showed four different kite designs. The kites were judged on decoration, how well they flew, and how stable they were in the air. 'Flying kites is easy,' said Adnan, 'but making them is hard. Come to my house, and I'll show you.' I decided to visit him. At his house, I drank cold tea and ate fish crackers. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to fix his kite, but I couldn't. I drove to the south of the state, towards Kuala Lumpur, into the mountains with rainforests. I took a wrong turn, and the road ended at a river. A boat was there to take people across. I saw a sign that said: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' The path was uphill, steep, and slippery. At the track, a man named Baba was waiting with tea. He had a tented kitchen and bamboo huts. I stayed there, trying not to think about insects. The night was very dark and noisy. A waterfall was nearby, and many animals made sounds. In the morning, I saw a great view of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. The wind and lightning hit the trees. I got very wet. Going downhill, I thought about my car being washed away. But my car was still there, covered in mud. In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, people asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' They were very friendly. Kelantan is famous for kites, but I remember it for the kind people.'

'What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping. Some people like it, some people don't. What kind of shopper are you? Abby Edwards asked some people ... A. Melanie, 22, dancer I love shopping! I spend a lot of money. When I have money, I go shopping. My boyfriend is the same. We shop together a lot. B. Brenda, 40, office manager I don't like shopping. My husband buys the food because he cooks. I buy clothes for my kids, but I don't like it. I don't buy things for myself often. When I do, I feel bad and don't tell my husband the real price. C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager I only buy what I need. I don't like shopping. I go when I must. I know what I want and I buy only that. Shopping makes me tired. D. Anita, 35, TV producer I shop sometimes. I know what I want and where to find it. I shop quickly. Sometimes I buy the wrong thing. E. Lizzie, 41, secretary I don't like shopping. I can't find what I want. The shops are noisy and messy. I don't shop for clothes often because people give me clothes. I buy food once a week. F. Lisa, 22, actress I like shopping. I go with my friends. We look around and sometimes buy things. I buy things I like. G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant I am careful when I shop. I know what I want. I don't buy a lot. I buy clothes but don't try them on. Sometimes they don't fit, but I don't mind.'

The Gallery has a new painting by Jan van Os, a Dutch artist from the 18th century. The painting shows flowers and fruit in bright colors. It is big and painted on wood. The artist signed it in 1777 and 1778 because he painted flowers from different seasons. Miss Violet Churchman gave this picture to the Gallery in memory of her sister. You can see it in Room 25.

A new exhibition called 'Painting in Spain during the late 18th century' is open in the Sunley Room. It started on 15 March. The exhibition shows works by Spanish painters Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. Other artists like Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, are also included. The exhibition is open until 31 May.

On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories with their pictures.

'MONEY What is money? Money is like a tool we use to buy things. We have pounds, dollars, and euros. You can use money to buy a book, sweets, or cinema tickets. But money is just paper or metal. Long ago, people did not have money. They did not have banks or shops. Mr. Green, the farmer, gave corn to Mr. Hive for honey. They traded things they had. Later, people made their own money to trade more easily. Now, every country has its own money.'

'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. She was the first woman scientist in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University. He gave her a very good education. This was special because most women could not study then. Hypatia studied in Athens and Rome. Then she went back to Alexandria to teach mathematics. She became famous for her new ideas. We do not have her books now, but she wrote important math books. Hypatia also liked technology and made some scientific tools. At that time, many rulers were afraid of science. People who liked science were in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked and killed in the street.'

Grass
Grass is a very successful plant. There are more than 9,000 types of grass. Grass grows everywhere in the world. It can grow in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic. Many animals live in grasslands. Small insects, birds, cows, and lions all need grass. Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or hurt. New leaves grow from under the soil, not from the top. This helps many animals live in one place. When animals eat the grass, it grows back fast, so they always have food.

Kal Kaur Rai loves fashion. She won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. As a child, she liked drawing clothes. Her parents own a supermarket, and she did not tell them she wanted to work in fashion. They thought she would do a different job, so she studied management at university. After university, she moved to London and worked in advertising. She needed nice clothes for work events but could not buy them, so she made her own skirts and tops. Her friends liked her clothes and asked her to make some for them. A small shop in London sold her clothes, and they were very popular. This made her happy, so she left her job and started her own clothing business with a PS20,000 loan. Her parents were not angry and said they would help her. Now, her clothes are in over 70 stores, and her business makes over PS500,000. Her clothes are in fashion magazines, and she designs for pop stars. 'Tom Cruise Tom Cruise is a very famous actor. But his life was not always easy. When he was a boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends. He liked acting in school plays. After High School, Tom went to New York to find a job. He worked as a porter and went to acting classes. In 1980, a film director named Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Title: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN?'
Bo is a cat. One day, Bo went into a big truck. The truck was for moving furniture. Bo had a big adventure! The truck driver found Bo after driving 500 kilometers. It was a long day. The driver and Bo were hungry. The driver gave Bo some milk. He tried to find Bo's owner. He called his last customers, but no one lost a cat. It was late, so the driver took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took Bo to an animal hospital.
Bo's owner was looking for her too. He looked everywhere. Then, he remembered the furniture truck at a neighbor's house. He remembered the company's name. He called the company. Soon, Bo went home safely.

'The Ghan Train Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train goes across Australia, from the warm north to the cold south. People call it the 'famous Ghan', but it is often late. A train line from Adelaide to Alice Springs was made in the 1920s, but it had problems with flooding. A new line was finished before my trip. The train is not very fast and is mostly for people on holiday. It is not as fancy as the Orient Express, but the food is very good. The railway was first made to carry goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to the south of Australia through Darwin and the train would save time and money. The Ghan says it is the first train to go from north to south. When I waited to get on the Ghan, everyone was excited. Most of the people traveling with me were older Australians. Our first stop was at Katherine, where the train waited for four hours. Some people took a boat trip. I got off the train at Alice Springs and went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group. We walked around the rock and watched the sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many people stop here. After Alice Springs, the view from the train is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land and cattle. On the third day, we reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. My trip was over, and even if the train was not perfect, it took me to some amazing places in Australia.'

'Climbing to the top of Britain Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. It is very cold there. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time on Ben Nevis. It was February, my first big winter climb. We went up the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It is 600 meters up - the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries'. These are like big bowls in the mountain, halfway up. We had tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need them because the snow is very hard, like ice. Even though some people in the group were very good climbers, we took safety things like lights, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather was good, with no strong winds, but we were still a bit nervous. Ben Nevis in winter is always hard. The path went up and my legs felt tired. I was the slowest in the group, so I had to rest more. The others waited for me, but when I got to them, they started again. I told myself to train better next time. After 200 meters, we got to Tower Ridge. It is only one and a half meters wide, and the mountain goes down a long way on each side. We had to stay calm and watch every step. After seven hours, we got to the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. But we were not lucky; there was mist. Going back down to camp is also hard. You need to read a map well. A wrong turn can be dangerous in winter. I was happy we took turns to read the map. That first time, I only felt happy when I was safe in the tent. But I made it to the top.'

Anna's New School
This week is very exciting. We moved to a new school building! The school is made of wood, like our old school. It is special because it is good for the environment. It took a long time to build. We watched the builders work. It was fun to see, but the machines were very loud. Sometimes, the builders stopped because of the rain. We thought it would never be finished.
Now, we have five big classrooms. They are bigger than the old ones. We also have a room for people in the town to have meetings. There is a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms. We will use them when the new sports field is ready.
When you come to the school, you see there are no heaters. The heat comes from us, the teachers, and the computers. The building keeps the heat and sound inside. When we sing, it sounds like a concert hall!
There is a tree on the roof. The builders put it there because it is a custom in Austria. The lights and computers get electricity from a wind turbine on a hill. We saw it yesterday. It is very big and goes around fast. We took pictures for the website.
We still need some parts of the school. We do plays for parents, but we go to the old school hall. The new hall will be ready next year. We are happy with our new school. Our teachers say we will learn faster here!

'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I left my bag on the bus. In my bag, I had my checkbook, address book, and my wallet with about Â£50 and some credit cards. When I noticed, it was too late. I am 72 years old, far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the road and cried. A young man asked me what was wrong. I told him, and he gave me money for the bus home. The bus driver said I could keep the money. I got home safely. Soon, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus. He said they found my bag and would bring it to me. I got my bag back with everything inside. I want to say thank you to everyone who helped me. They were very kind and honest. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

'Sharks Sharks are big fish in the ocean. Many people think they are scary. Sharks can see very well in the water. They can also feel when things move near them. This helps them catch small fish to eat. Sharks are not the same as other fish. Most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and stay alive. This means they do not sleep much. If you turn a shark on its back, it stops moving. This helps scientists study sharks. They can learn more about these interesting animals.'

**THE ICEHOTEL**
The Arctic is very cold in winter. Not many people live there. In 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit made an art show in a snow building called an igloo. This was in a small town called Jukkasjarvi. Many people came to see it. Some people decided to sleep in the igloo. They liked it very much. This gave the idea to make an ice hotel. Now, the ICEHOTEL is famous.
Every winter, people come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel. They use snow and ice. The hotel opens in parts. The first part opens in December. The hotel is finished by January 7th. The hotel melts in spring when it gets warm.
Inside the hotel, it is not colder than -5Â°C to -8Â°C. Guests get warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves. It is good to bring sweaters, a scarf, and thick socks. You can buy these on the ICEHOTEL website. They will be in your room when you arrive.
The hotel is in Jukkasjarvi. It is 200 km above the Arctic Circle. It is 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle is a new furniture shop. It opened at midnight last Thursday. Many people, about 6,000, came to the shop. There were special offers. A leather sofa was on sale for Â£45 until 3 am. A bed was on sale for Â£30 between 3 am and 8 am. The shop's normal hours are 9 am to 9 pm every day. But for the first day, it was open for 24 hours. However, the shop closed after 30 minutes. A police officer said: 'We knew many people would come, but they were not patient. The shop was full, so the managers closed the doors. People outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold. They did not want to wait in line. Also, many cars were trying to get to the car park. Some people left their cars in the road and walked to the shop. This blocked the road.' One customer, Jenny Smith, got into the shop. She said: 'I waited for three hours. I did not have time to buy what I wanted. The staff were calm and explained the situation. It was not safe. I will come back when they open again, but I will not wait in line again.'

'Free-diving in the Caribbean Tanya Streeter is very good at free-diving. Free-diving is a sport where people dive deep into the ocean with just one breath. In 2003, Tanya Streeter went 120 meters deep into the ocean and came back up without help. She held her breath for over three and a half minutes. This made her the first woman to break a man's world record in any sport. Fourteen safety divers watched her dive. Some people think free-diving is dangerous, but Tanya says it is safe if you train well and focus on safety. Tanya trains a lot. She spends most of her time training in the gym. She also trains in the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to make her heart strong. She does not run because she wants to protect her knees. Instead, she walks fast to stay fit. When she practices diving, she travels away from home. She does fourteen dives in four weeks, with a rest day between each dive. Rest is important so she does not get tired. When Tanya is not diving, she talks to people about sports and helps with environmental projects. She grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman and loved swimming and exploring the sea. Tanya says her life now is like her childhood dreams. She is famous in some countries, so people listen to her about the environment. Tanya is in her thirties and wants to keep breaking her own records. She started free-diving at twenty-five and does not want to stop for many years.'

CARTOON FILMS
Cartoon films can show many things. If you can draw it, you can make it move in a movie. New ideas and computer programs make cartoons fun for everyone. In the 1970s, people thought cartoons were only for kids. But some directors had new ideas. They showed that both adults and kids can enjoy cartoons. Not all cartoon films were good. The Black Cauldron did not do well. It was too scary for kids and too simple for adults. Directors learned from this, and film companies started making money again.

Title: Caroline Benson's First TV Role
Caroline Benson is a new TV star. She talks about her first TV role. 
Caroline is a student at university. She did not think she would act in a TV show in her first year. She only acted in school plays before. She loved a book called "The Finnegans" since she was eleven. Her grandmother said she was like a character in the book, Polly Finnegan. Caroline always wanted to play Polly.
Before university, Caroline traveled for a year. When she was in Chile, her mother sent her an email. The email said they wanted to make "The Finnegans" into a TV show. Caroline wanted to try for the role. Her mother sent her photo to the director. The director wanted to meet Caroline. She flew back home and got the role.
Caroline started filming one week after university began. She got permission to leave university for three weeks. When she came back, she woke up at 6:00 am to write her essays. She did not tell her university friends about the TV show, but they found out and were happy for her.
Caroline had a great time acting. She wants to be an actress after university. Her grandfather was an opera singer, but no one else in her family acts. She tried for other TV roles but did not get any yet. She also acted in two college plays. 
Caroline is going to Greece with friends for the summer. She is excited for the future.

I have learned a lot since we started. I wrote this book to share what I learned. I think we can run a good business and still keep our values. This book is not just about business or my life.
